reviews.review: Free entrance. Went to visit the Cathedral while waiting for my family. Entrance is free of charge, and I felt a good atmosphere inside. Lots of candles and despite long queue to kiss the icons, it was quite inside and you could sit and do you prayers.

Attend the Service at 6pm. Its a beautiful Cathedral and a little busy one too. We were told that the service takes place twice a day.. One at 6pm daily and its surely a right time to visit the Cathedral.
There two desks selling souvenirs within the Cathedral and they seemed better priced than those outside.

Get there in the morning. Kazan is gorgeous. But, it's even better when there aren't people, vendors, and tour buses obstructing your view. The cathedral is situated pretty close to the Spilt Blood Church and really within walking distance of the Winter Palace and the waterway. I suggest getting up early and getting out there within an hour after sunrise. It's really worth it to capture the cathedral in all it's glory!
Icon Cathedral. Lots of icons here and lots of people queuing up to kiss them and pray. Beautiful paintings, but not as nice as St Isaac for me. However, worth a visit on your itinerary

Right on Nevsky Prospekt. Kazan Cathedral is situated on Nevsky Prospekt, across the street from the Singer house and close to the Bank Bridge with beautiful winged lions.The colonnade to both sides of the entrance is impressive and reminds of St. Peter's basilica in Rome.

Nice. It is on the Nevsky Prospekt street so it is easy to find. The cathedral is quite huge. The location is near to the Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood which you can clearly see from the opposite side.

Mason cathedral, Kutuzov burial place, worth the visit. After seeing the Church of our Savior on Spilled Blood, we continued up - having the canal on our right - and ended in front of the wonder. Reminds me of the Karlskirche in Vienna for it's Masonic symbols and numerous exterior and interior columns. My recommendation is to see it during day time. The entrance into the church is free of charge.If you have some interest in Masonic symbols and architecture, look above the front main entrance, and have a walk around the cathedral before going inside. The inside also hosts, apart from the eye of providence above the altar, the burial tomb of Field Marshal Kutuzov, an 18th-19th century hero for the Russian Empire - think about how Napoleon lost in Russia to get the idea.Absolutely worth a visit, inside and out.

A suprise service. As an independant tourist I was informed that there was some type of worship at 5 pm on a Sunday. I was keen to hear some singing. I travelled by bus from my hotel. ON arrival there was a fascinating type of wedding ceremony with accompanying choral music. The couple being blessed seem to have three children so it was a little difficult to determine what exactly was the ceremony that was takinig place. Anyhow a memorable visit.
Imposing religious monument.. Huge imposing building which bears testament to religous beliefs.Visit when a service is being held for amazing experience.
Beautiful church. It is a massive church with active service. We were impressed by the paintings on the roof and the huge pillars

Our Lady of Kazan. Kazan Cathedral alongside Nevsky Prospekt at Griboyedov Canal has several names: Kazanskiy Kafedralniy Sobor (in Russian language, Каза́нский кафедра́льный собо́р), or Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan. A rose by any other name… This is a cathedral of the Russian Orthodox Church, meaning there are no pews. Worshipers must stand during services. Construction began in 1801 and continued for 10 years, completed just before Napoleon invaded Russia’s capital at the time (St Pete). Mikhail Kutuzov was Russia’s commander-in-chief and prevailed over Napoleon. Kutuzov is interred in the cathedral in 1813, two years after the cathedral’s consecration. Architect Andrey Voronikhin modelled the Empire Style design after St Peter Basilica in Rome. The distinctive semicircular colonnade caught my attention when walking along Nevsky Prospekt. The interior has numerous columns, which echoes the exterior colonnade and seems inspired by a palatial hall, towering 70 meters long and 62 meters high. There are oodles of sculptures and religious icons from the early 1800s, and a gilded iron grille separating the small square behind is exquisite.
Still functional. This is still a functional worship place. it is not as beautiful or preserved as St Isaacs cathedral, but it worths a visit for the architecture and the ongoing action.

Momentous from the outside and gorgeous inside. A marvel of architecture and a work of art. The icons and arts will inspire anyone regardless of their faith. I found it beautiful and inspiring. Many visitors are praying and that is also nice to see.

Architecture and the spirituality. This is a truly amazing building. It is not your traditional Russian Orthodox Church. It is a classical building yet full of Russian Orthodox icons.It is a wonderful living place - just to sit and appreciate the devotion of so many people.
Another nice tourist spot.. This is also close to the Lions Gate Bridge and the Church of the Spilled Blood. It is also across the Singer Building

Breath taking.. Sooo beautiful... we visited on a Sunday so we had the opportunity to participate to the Holy ceremony. Breath taking church. Breath taking experience. You can feel the holiness of the place. No entry fees are required. There are few souvenir shops for church items.Amazing church.
A living church. We enjoyed being able to share the experience of this extraordinary cathedral with local attending confession
Beautiful!. Definitely worht it! The cafe Singer in front of the cathedral is an excellent spot to sit and have a coffee while enjoyning the view with this beautiful cathedral

Very elaborate interior. With the gardens and fountain outside Kazan Cathedral is in a perfect setting and when you go inside you will not be disappointed. It is beautiful and highly decorated and free to get in. Well worth a look.
Beautiful. I felt that I just visited some place that was very holy, wonderfully decorated as all Russian churches are
Good. In nevsky street you will find every where you should visit.it is located there.and you can enjoy watching the building
nevsky prospekt. very impressive facade and interiors, easy to get to, near gostiny dvor, easy access from metro station

Is a must!. Impressive orthodox cathedral at the very heart of St. Petersburg. Unusual architecture, Kutuzov's tomb along with french castles keys and other trophies which became a part of the Russian history.

Another architectural gem!. In a historic city full of impressive architecture and design Kazan Cathedral is another stand out building. I barely had much time to see anything in full detail, but I definitely noticed this as we drove by and later stopped quickly for some photos on my tour. Very nice and worthy of a bit of your time in the city. Enjoy.

A peaceful visit . The minute you enter you just sense the peacefulness this church brings. No picture taking is allowed here just absorb the ambience. Open confession you can see how the Russians do their confessions. With a priest, bible and rosary.

Beautiful Roman Style. Felt more like a Roman temple than a church given the architecture. The area around the church is worth a visit in and of itself. The inside offers a stunning display of Russian Orthodox icons and decorations, and Roman Style frescoes depicting biblical events. If your seeking a destination that fills your urge to bathe in the atmosphere of the 19th century in Russia, you absolutely must visit this extraordinary cathedral. *free entry as well
Very nice Cathedral. Kazan Cathedral is very nice and impressive. The Cathedral is located on Nevsky Prospect so you can't miss it.

A very meaningful place for Christians. A very gorgeous cathedral, it is free and is used for religious services so the dress code matters and no pictures allowed inside. It has a very important religious icon so this place is visited by Christians from different countries, there is normally a long line to the icon inside.

Beautiful Cathedral. This cathedral is located just along the Nevsky Prospect , it is surrounded by a nice garden but what is capturing your attention is the huge colonnade which seems to hug what is all around. Inside there are beautiful frescos, religious icons and rich chandeliers and all of them are enriched by gold and precious gems. What is a real beauty is the magnificent portal finely decorated and full of gem which can give you the real measurement of an Orthodox Church.
Very impressive!!!. Occasionally we attended a pray. It was real spectacle.. Staying there, I was thinking where were all these people just 15 years ago in Soviet period???
Huge, beautiful and impressive!. This is an orthodox church of amazing scale and beauty. It is an active church so you will be surrounded by tourists but mainly worshipers. You really should see it!
One of the main monuments of the city. Close to ths gostiny dvor and a must visit for a first time visitor of the city. For non chrisitans it takes just a few minutes to visit this cathedral.

Greek Architecture. The cathedral has Greek Architecture outside. It is a functioning Cathedral and the interiors provide an atmosphere to open your hearts in prayer. A must see when in St. Petersburg

The Church.. Working church which is open daily gathering a lot of religious people. In the same time architect monument gathering a lot of tourists. Very beautiful inside and magnificent outside. Must see.

Worth seeing for the icon of Our Lady of Kazan. Even though it looks massive from the outside and lots of people were inside, there was a respectful hush and serenity so it was a much more peaceful experience than I expected. It's an active church so there was no fee for entrance but you could buy candles to light. There was a big queue to pay respects to the Our Lady of Kazan icon. Women generally cover their heads as a mark of respect.

Nice Landmark . The Kazan Cathedral with its extended arms toward the Nevsky Avenue is a very impressive sight. However when it come to photograph the site, it is almost impossible due to its size and limited space. During the morning hours, the sun make it even more awkward to take any snap shot. The interior of the cathedral is different. The local come to pay respect and worship in the cathedral. With photograph is allow in a discreet way, wonderful photos can be taken. Spend most time inside instead of outside.

I left my heart there.. Went to Russia with a tour group, however as I am Russian Orthodox I left the hotel we were staying at early each morning to attend Divine Liturgy. My fellow worshippers helped me as much as they could with the language barrier, providing me with a translator for confession. I was made to feel welcome and it was the best start one could have to the day.

Big stone big building. Enjoy this cathedral from the street. Cross away is the bleeding church and the bridge walking area. I hear that there is a lion statue behind the cathedral that you touch the feet gonna bring you prospherity. Well worth to try . Fortune calling
Interesting to see. One of the oldest church. If you are careful, you can find on the walls the keys of French city that Russians brought back after the defeat of Napoleon.
Beautiful Cathedral . This is a working cathedral so no flashes and noise should be kept to a minimal. The place is huge and so beautiful inside. It felt very peaceful and serene.

Kazan Cathedral...St Petersburg. The cathedral looks enormous with its semi circular wide expanse of 96 columns. Because the altar of an orthodox church is supposed to face east, the cathedral 'entrance' from Nevsky Prospekt is actually the back of the church. As with the other churches, it is striking to me to see that there are no seats. It is considered rude to sit in the presence of God. This is particularly interesting as religion was forbidden during most of the communist years. So many generations have grown up with no religious leanings, much less teachings. With no pews however, it is easier to get a feel for the layout of the church and to appreciate the beautiful mosaic floors and the opulent frescoes on the walls and ceilings. The cathedral since 1991 is currently used for religious purposes, but in the past as with all Russian cathedrals, it was repurposed as the times were changing and there was no need for religious buildings.Women should wear a hat or a scarf over their hair.
Mini st pauls cathedral . On the Nevsky prospect looking spectacular in the middle of the shopping streets, didn't go in as very busy but beautiful in its own right.

Nice...although not that spectacular. This is a nice cathedral, although not as impressive as others you will find in St Petersburg. It's a bit dark and the entrance is free since it is a worship place.Very nice altar.

Excellent icons. Beautiful Cathedral. Wonderful to see so many people at prayer. and lighting candles and enjoying the Cathedral. Icons were beautiful and we took our time walking around looking at them. Really worth a visit.

A great cathedral. For me, this was a "true" cathedral with people praying and taking comfort from the icons located in the church. The icons on the walls were the most "contemporary" for me. I just loved the place and recommend it.
Interesting. You can see people queing for a private praying at an icon. The church is beatiful, and somewhat gives an "exotic" impression. Highly recommended.
love it. another magical place at St peter, spare 2 hours to check most of it, such a wonderful place as a must see in the city.Enjoy it

Impressive. Great interior, classic Russian style. Luckily we visited the interior when the religious cult was ongoing, quite impressive. A must in Saint Petersburg. Pictures can't be taken in the interior. Free visit.

You're part of a Tour, you're ok, not on your own in this place.. Entered this church attracted by the "sacra music" from the street while passing by. As I entered the recint, noticed the signs "no photography", so, I acknowledged. Once inside the first thing I noticed was people taking videos and photos with flash!. Those people were parts of several tours. Observing that, I pulled my iPhone and started recording. Immediately I got a bunch of babushkas, and a man, pushing me, shoving and screaming at me; they kicked me out of that place.Basically, religion is not the issue, it is money; you are paying for a tour, you take all the video and pics you want. You're on your own?, watch out for those religious freaks.Not very nice people.Later on I entered another church, and I recorded all I wanted of video, no issues.

Religious and peaceful place. I'm not a religious people, but once I've walked in, I could feel that strong power of p3 ace. Inside was terribly quiet, many religious people came and standed in a queue to wait for praying. They sold some religious books and accessories inside. Photos are allowed and free.

Beautiful place of worship. The Kazan Cathedral is an active place of worship and female visitors are advised to take a scarf to cover their heads, whilst male visitors should remove their hats. It is an excellent place to visit.

Beautiful Cathedral. An other beautiful piece of architecture in the heart of Saint Petersburg. Unlike the Saint Isaak's Catherdal and The Church of Our Savior on the Spilled Blood, Kazan Cathedral is a functional Orthodox church. Very beautiful inside with the crystal columns at the altar.

Definitely worth a 'drop in' while on Nevsky. This is a very impressive cathedral containing countless beautiful mosaics. We were fortunate to view a religious ceremony, which provided an authentic experience. It's definitely worth a 'drop in' while on Nevsky.
Just awesome. Kazan Cathedral is just one of many places of interest in St. Petersburg. The interior is mesmerizing with old iconic pictures .

Beautiful Sunset over the Kazan. I caught the sunset here and it was stunning. The grass areas are a nice place to sit on a sunny day and take in the City. Right by the main street with a lot happening.
Not interesting. We visited the church at 8/16. We like the garden in the yard. Nice stop. But inside we didnt find anything interesting.

Functioning Cathedral at Nevsky Prospekt. While perhaps not as spectacular as Our Saviour on the Spilled Blood or St Isaac's (how spoiled we can get after those!), Kazan is an impressive cathedral with a unique neoclassical columned promenade at its north side (facing Nevsky). This is a functional Christian orthodox cathedral so be sure to remain respectful and quiet (no photography permitted) while there. Whatever your orientation, slender beeswax candles can be purchased and placed in one of the many votive stands for your prayer of thanks for your spectacular STPB vacation, to the God of your choosing.
One of the Five must sees in St Petersburg. With Catherine's Palace, Peterhof, Spilled Blood and St Issacs this is one of my five must sees in St Petersburg. Be ready to be overwhelmed in this city.
Massive building. Massive building having huge pillars flanking the cathedral. Inside is a small though much revered icon of Mother Mary. It was dimly lit inside.
Huge but a bit gloomy. Definitely worth a visit just for its size alone. It's a bit gloomier than other churches but interesting as part of the whole picture of St. Petersburg.
Little Vatican. Little Vatican and a remarkable landmark. The best viewe is from the first floor of the Dom Knigi, opposite of the street. It is a cafe so enjoy a coffee and a view.
Very beautiful cathedral. Been there at 8:30 am and it was open. Good start for a visiting day as almost all other monuments of St. Petersburg only open after 10:30 am.
Free and near the subway Nevsky Prospect. Inside the church in small it's the outside that impresses the tourist. Enter, see and go on to the next attraction.
Great place to visit!. It's a nice place to visit when you're in the city centre. I just dislike a small fence around this building.

Yet another church, but worth stopping into.. We were lucky enough to go twice - once two years ago and once on the Orthodox version of Easter Sunday. Whilst there we saw a ceremony taking place and that really WAS worth seeing. If you go at any other time its a nice, big, impressive church - just like the thousands of others in the world. Its infamy means that you should probably stop by nonetheless just to tick the box. Fortunately you are almost certain to walk past it during you time in St Petes so take the 15 mins required. Ladies will have to cover up a bit. If you happen to be religious then you may get a bit more from the experience, but either way you can make this really worth you time by going when there is a service on.
Great Building. Did a private tour to see this. Did not get inside but really wanted to see the outside. Worth a look.

Holy place - must see. We went to the church on a rainy day. No entrance fees is required and inside u cannot take pictures. Great place for prayer and grandiose structure. No loud speaking inside. Love it and recommend visiting.
The exterior draws you to it. Unique architecture prompts one to stop and look. This Cathedral is home to one of the most important icons to Russians/ in Russian history. Did not visit the interior.
Wonderful Orthodox Church. A wonderful orthodox church. Notre-Dame-de-Kazan it's on the Boulevard Nevsky. Please note that taking pictures are forbidden.
Beautiful church. An actual house of worship, so be respectful if you want to venture inside to see the beautiful architecture and decor - no photos. A place of peace and reflection.
Free to enter. It is stuffed full of icons and beautiful paintings but very busy. Its hard to manoeuvre around but well worth going in. We were lucky enough to be tyere when a choir was singing too.

It was returned to Russian Orthodox Church. The Kazan Cathedral was an 'Atheism and Religion' museum in the times of the Soviet Union. I remember when I went there with my classmates looking at stands of photographs telling about atheism and religion in USSR. Later the Kazan Cathedral was returned to Russian Orthodox Church and there services are held. Especially beautiful service takes place on Easter night.The Kazan Cathedral was built by architect Voronikhin and reminds small copy of the St.Peter Catedral in Rome. A beautiful fluted colonnade decorates its facade.

Historic Cathedral Now A Living Church Again. It would be hard to miss Kazan Cathedral as it sits dramatically on Nevsky Prospect in St. Petersburg near the center of just about everything.The Cathedral itself was built at the beginning of the 1800s, but was turned into a memorial to the Russian victory over Napoleon after1812. There is a statue of Mikhail Kutuzov, the Russian general who orchestrated that victory, out front, and his remains are interred inside.The exterior is dramatic and was modelled after St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. While large, the neoclassical interior isn't quite as impressive as those in nearby St. Isaac's Cathedral or the Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood.The cathedral was closed with the Communist revolution in 1917 and later converted, oddly enough, into a "Museum of Atheism" that was viewed with embarassment even at the time. It has now been returned to the Russian Orthodox Church. A couple of notes: First, this is now a living church, so you'll need to respect the worshipers and many areas are inaccessible during service times. They also expect women to wear scarves over their heads, although we saw many who did not.Second, the area around the cathedral is fine, but a few blocks to the west there is an area we were warned by locals to avoid.This impressive cathedral is easy to visit and free. It's definitely worth your time to come here while in St. Petersburg.
Imressive. This cathedral is impressive in its size and the that interior features numerous sculptures and icons created by the best Russian artists of the day.

St. Peter's Rome Look Alike!. If you travel down Nevsky Prospekt, you cannot fail to notice the impressive Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan. The Kazan Cathedral looks very similar to the Basilica of St. Peter’s in Rome. It was built in 1801 by the Russian architect Andrei Voronikhin. Although closed for services during most of the Soviet era, the cathedral is open today and is a wonderful example of a working Russian Orthodox Church. It has an impressive stone colonnade, encircling a small garden and central fountain. It was intended to be the country's main Orthodox Church. After the war of 1812 (during which Napoleon was defeated) the church became a monument to Russian victory. Captured enemy banners were put in the cathedral and the famous Russian Field Marshal Mikhail Kutuzov, who won the most important campaign of 1812, was buried inside the church. Open Monday-Friday: 8:30 a.m.-8:00 p.m. - Saturday & Sunday: 6:30 a.m.-8:00 p.m. Admission: Free – Women should cover their hair with a scarf, hat or hood while inside the Kazan Cathedral.
Big and impressive . The line was long. Many people tried to enter but the view inside was worthwhile. It's part of Russian history. And an important part so make en effort to enter and be impressed

True House of Worship. This house of worship is a Russian Orthodox Church on the Nevsky Prospekt in Saint Petersburg. It is dedicated to Our Lady of Kazan, probably the most venerated icon in Russia. During our visit there were numerous individuals praying, worshipping and in a queue to touch and pray at the relic of Holy Mother of Kazan. The exterior actually looks like a building of Parliament but the interior contains beautiful religious adornments.

A real place of worship - not a museum. We visited this cathedral as part of a tour with the Church on Spilled Blood and St Isaac's cathedral. This one is a full-time working church and whilst not nearly as opulent as the other two churches it had a much more spiritual feeling. There were queues of the faithful visiting a shrine of the Holy Mother of Kazan and Russian Orthodox nuns were in evidence. Whilst not as impressive architecturally, this was for me the most interesting in showing the revival of Russian Orthodox religion after the Soviet era. It was modelled on St Peter's in Rome.Some visitors did not seem to honour the fact that this is a living church - knees and shoulders should be covered but not everyone abided by this simple rule of respect. Photography is not allowed.
Kazan Cathedral. A very very busy place, not as stunning as other Cathedrals, it is a working Cathedral so plenty people praying and touching different areas within.

Interesting Architecture in a Functioning Church. A Russian Orthodox Church with a flavor of Rome, namely St. Peters. The architecture on the outside is frankly more interesting than the interior, although it was unique to see worshipers praying while visitors were gazing around. Admision is free, I would rate this place as much less important than the other major churches.
Interesting building. Nice architecture.It is Orthodox, but from outside reminds a little on St.Peter Basilica in Rome. Worth entering.
Nice cathedral. It is nice, but a pity they do not let taking pictures. It is full of observant people, and it is free of charge.

A living place of worship. It was pouring rain when we visited so it was good to get inside. Unlike most Russian cathedrals, this one is no longer a museum, but is once again a living place of worship. Hence, entry is free, and photography forbidden. As a matter of courtesy, women should wear a head scarf and men remove your hats.More austere interior than most other churches with large pillars and icons rather than paintings and mosaics. Very atmospheric.

You simply have no reason not to visit Kazan Cathedral. The Kazan Cathedral is on your way from Nevsky prospekt, it is free to enter because it is an operating church and interior is beautiful. Don't miss this place because the icon of Holy Mother of Kazan is on display there.
Good for Photographs. Nice cathedral, visited during my city tour. Spent 30 minutes which is more than enough. Good for taking photos and roam around.

Lovely working cathedral, and very different to the usual Orthodox over the top explosion in a paint shop!. This is on the main drag, Nevsky Prospekt. The first thing that struck me is how this building looks like St. Peter’s in Rome. And when you read the blurb, it did in fact follow the design of St Peters. It was free to enter, and is well worth a peek inside.Be respectful, this is a working cathedral and although it is not so over-the-top compared to the typical religious monuments of Russia (in fact it is comparatively dull), it has its own inner peace with queues of worshippers taking communion and lighting candles when we were there. I am not a religious person (brought up a protestant, converted to Islam, and am a confirmed atheist), but I am fascinated by the seductive emotive power of religion – and this place absolutely oozes it. Lovely feeling !

Majestic. The church is big, high and long. Let's say that's just Russian proportions. The church is free and it was full of locals praying there,so try to be respectful and quiet while walking around. It's definitely a good stop to do in the Nevsky Prospekt.

An insight into religion. The exterior is imposing. The interior is quite dark and restrained, with the focus being the eponymous icon. For War and Peace fans, it is the site of Kutuzov's burial and there is a statue of him outside in some pleasant gardens.

Stunning, and so easy to visit.. Right on Nevsky Prospekt this is a church you must visit. Unlike many other churches in SPB this is not a museum. Here you will see stunning icons and if you are as lucky as I was you will get a taste of the acoustics when the choir accompanies the service.

Colonnade Inspired by St. Peter's. We had some extra time before The Hermitage opened so stopped by this Cathedral during a morning service. It was not as ornate as Church of Spilled Blood, but was a handsome church. This was also the 'birthday' of the icon for the church, so it was a special time. We were able to see the doors at the altar opened.
Beautiful. This is one of the functioning churches in St.Peterburg, very beautiful baroque church, no admission fee.
Nice for stopping and exploring. Really good place to stop on the schedule of exploring St. Petersburg. A lot of history inside as well as some seating outside to have a rest.

Landmark just at the Nevsky prospect!. Another icon of the orthodox architecture!
Women have to cover their hair, so take this into account.

Nice Place. the cathedral is real huge and look like big castle
the interior designs and icons are from 14's century .
Must go . If you go to St Petersburg and don't here you're crazy. Amazing inside and out. Could spend all day there. The specticle is incredible. A must see.
A beautiful cathedral. One of the most beautiful cathedrals in Russia. To appreciate the true beauty of the cathedral, you should attend on a Sunday morning when you can see a service.

Still in Use, be respectful. As we were entering my wife was having difficulty with her head scarf (always cover in churches,and men a note here, as in Europe only children and tourists wear shorts) and a Sweet babushka swooped in and assisted her, commenting pleasantly in Russian something or other. We noticed that all these churches and Cathedrals are still used by observant orthodox, young and old alike

Beautiful inside - worth a visit. It is worth a visit, and you should time your visit to coincide with a service. This was my first visit to a Russian Orthodox cathedral so the unique style compared to other cathedrals was very interesting to see.

Beautiful cathedral in St. Petersburg. The Kazan Cathedral is located along the Nevsky Prospekt; it’s the U-shaped building with lots of columns. While nowhere as colourful as the Church of the Saviour on Spilled Blood, nor as ornate as the gold-domed St. Isaac’s Cathedral, Kazan Cathedral is still quite beautiful nonetheless, especially the interior! Entrance to the cathedral is free, and visitors are welcome to enter and observe. The cathedral also happens to open daily, so you can visit any day.If you are interested in visiting the Church of the Saviour on Spilled Blood, you can cross over to the opposite side and walk along the waterway to reach it. It’s quite fool-proof since you can already see the colourful church from Kazan Cathedral.

Amazing!. Really interesting and beautiful place! Very high ceilings! It is a cultural heritage of Russia! I am very impressed… The place is located in the city centre, around the flowers grow and it's all very inspiring. Amazing!

Worth a visit!. Kazan Cathedral is worth of visit while in St. Petersburg. Although it cannot rival The Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood and St. Isaac;s Cathedral, it is very beautiful inside. When we visited, in November, there were many locals praying and kneeling in the church, which gave us the impression that the cathedral still works for mass.

Iconic Cathedral. A prominent icon on Nevsky Prospekt, this was my favorite cathedral in St. Petersburg. Although not as spectacular looking as the nearby Church on Spilled Blood, you get a sense of real Russian Orthodox worship inside here. Entrance is free and you get a chance to observe, pray, meditate on your own schedule. Prices for icons, worship items, etc. are more reasonably priced than at other cathedrals as well.
Dominates Nevsky Prospect. Interesting building. Did not go inside, but the gardens provide a welcome (and free) spot to sit down on a hot summer's day.

Russian orthodox church. This is a working church and not a museum so no photography is allowed. Most of the Russian women covered their heads but I didn't feel uncomfortable with mine uncovered. There was a long line to approach and I he a special icon. Free. Took less than one hour to see.

Unheralded gem. Sandwiched midway between the more famous St Isaacs cathedral and church of the Spilled Blood - this small sweet active church is a great antidote to the over crowded tour crammed more famous places When services are on, seeing locals line up for blessings deepens the majesty of the setting. Tiny enough to see quickly yet detailed enough to enjoy - you won't be disappointed and you can easily walk to it from either of the others. Enjoyed it the most of the three - including the small collection of reliquaries.

So glad we went to this gem. If i wasn't for our guide, we'd not have visited this cathedral which, as you can tell, is modelled on the Vatican because the Russians wanted it as a centre of the Orthodox religion. It's stunning to look at from the outside and inside it houses a religious picture people queue up to touch and make a wish through. It's definitely one to check out and it's right there at the side of the main shopping street. So glad our guide took us in and explained the history behind the place (village kids says there's a religious picture buried somewhere, adults dig, find it, put it in this church to bring Russia lots of good luck).

Impressive building with free access. This is the only great building in St. Petersburg which is open to the public. It is a functioning Orthodox church, so expect to find religious service or chanting virtually anytime. Impressive interiors.
Another beautiful cathedral. Situated right next to a metro station. Does not disappoint us when we visit its interior. And the entrance is free of charge.

Russian Orthodox Mass - Unique Experience. This is a great church to see and visit. No pictures are allowed because it is a working church today. We were able to watch a mass, which was such a unique experience. The church was built to commemorate a victory over the French, and there are still historical pieces in the church from the victory. Beautiful building, the size is enormous, would highly recommend.

impressive classic cathedral. Worth visiting to eyewitness that even after 80 years of communist rule the faith in God remain .Watch the prayers standing in a long queue to kiss an icon.Convenient location on the west side of Nevsky Prospect.Free entrance.
Awesome icon!. Amazing to see the number of people in line to see the famous icon - definitely worth your time to stop in!

Witness real orthodox mass!. Camera was not allowed, because unlike touristy spilt blood, this is real working cathedral. I was lucky to walk in when they were conducting mass (not sure, if it's not called mass). There were about 6 priests chanting and reading, people were praying and crossing themselves. Other people were lighting candles, kissing icons, while nuns in black habits cleaning candle stands. Very somber atmosphere. Also this is the resting place of kutzsov who led Russian army to victory against French. his resting place was surrounded by French standards and keys of the city taken from surrendering French army. kutzsov statue is outside as well. middle of the centre roof outside has Freemason symbol. Well worth a visit.
nice too see. nice to see, but not too spectacular in my eyes. However, many orthodox come here to get blessed after praying.

The less impressive cultural attraction in St Petersburg. Do not get me wrong, it is a great place, specially inside with its richness of icons. Outside, for me as roman, was less impressive and also the colors not so attractive like the ther cathedral in town. Just stunning cathedral in Nevsky Prospekt !. This elegant, arched colonnade of one magnificent and sacred edifice, we just couldn't miss, being in Nevsky Prospekt. The location is great, since it is situated in the magnificent Nevsky Prospekt, and with its right wing, it is adjacent to the kanal of Griboyedov ( great russian poet and dramatist). This Cathedral is also known as the Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan. So, it is an Orthodox Church that is dedicated to Our Lady of Kazan probably the most respected icon in Russia. And from this fact, there is an issue, that this Kazan Sobor (Cathedral) is not only one remarkable museum but also a church with full service. It consists of one main and central columned portal with the pediment on the top of it, and behind arises a colossal dome with the golden cross. To the right and left, range the curved colonnade and end with the two medium, triumphal portals as a memorial to the Russian victory against Napoleon.Here in Cathedral is interred Mikhail Kutuzov himself and Alexander Pushkin wrote some celebrated verses about him, while the poet meditated over his sepulchre.In front of this flanked portals are placed the bronze statues of Kutuzov and Barclay de Tolly ( Kutuzov's eminent general).There is a very nice lawn before the Cathedral and also a fountain and wooden benches on the tiny gravelled path. Very pleasant spot for meetings with acquaintances.We really enjoyed here, within this Kazanskaya Square, formed by the elegant design and structure of Kazansky Sobor.

Worth a visit for Christians and architecture fans. I enjoyed this visit. It is free and peacefully quiet. If you enjoy architecture, you can easily drop 45 minutes to an hour here. As a Roman Catholic, I enjoyed comparing and contrasting the Orthodox-style architecture to that which I've seen in the hundreds of Roman-style churches I've been in. The usual rules apply for visiting a holy place: Men should be covered past the knees - preferably pants - and no hats; women should be dressed conservatively and preferably have some kind of head cover, though I don't think any of this is tightly enforced, I visited in the early Spring when it was still cool outside, so nobody was dressed in shorts etc. anyway. This is a good place to sit and silently pray if you are religious. There are also gift/merchandise stands on either exit where you can buy icons or Christian jewelry for quite a reasonable price. N.B.: The sign on the outside of the cathedral says (in Russian) to not take photos. Again, this is not enforced and architecture geeks like myself will not be able to resist the temptation to snap an occasional photo. Just be respectful and discreet and turn off your flash, and I don't think anyone will care.

Impressive Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan. Whilst taking a stroll along Nevsky Prospekt, the main thoroughfare in St. Petersburg, one cannot fail to notice the impressive Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan. The cathedral was inspired by the Basilica of St. Peter's in Rome. The cathedral was named after the "miracle-making" icon of Our Lady of Kazan. After the war of 1812 (during which Napoleon was defeated) the church became a monument to Russian victory. Russian Field Marshal Mikhail Kutuzov, who won the most important campaign of 1812, was buried inside the church. The cathedral's interior, with its numerous columns, echoes the exterior colonnade and is reminiscent of a palatial hall, being 69 metres in length and 62 metres in height. The interior features numerous sculptures and icons created by the best Russian artists of the day. A wrought iron grille separating the cathedral from a small square behind it is sometimes cited as one of the finest ever created.

Not interesting. I was very disappointed both by the exterior and interior of the building. The outside does not look like a church. It looks like the parliament building. When you enter the church, you do not feel that serenity you have in many other churches.

Interesting church as it is an active place of worship and not a museum. Active church. Looks like St Peters at the Vatican. Russian Orthodox Christian religion. Large number of icons with a large number of worshippers paying tribute by kissing the glass. Cover your head with a scarf to pay proper respect.
Kazan Cathedral. Of historical interest, purchases here at some stalls may only be made in Rubles however there is one near the exit that accepts the Euro as well.

Beautiful cathedral. Built in early 19th c. With semi-circular colonnade this is a striking building which contains a very early copy of the Our Lady of Kazan icon. Discovered underground in 1579 this icon was raised to Palladian status - that is to say an icon capable of defending the country. The original was stolen from Kazan in 1904 for its gold and bejewelled frame and the icon was probably destroyed , though this is disputed. The old copies in St Petersburg and Moscow are highly venerated and you will see the continuous queue waiting patiently to kiss the icon, which it is rumoured was carried round the fortifications during the ww2 siege.
another attraction near saviour of blood. entry is free, photography is prohibited, some part of the cathedral was undergoing some repair work, very peaceful place .

Breathtaking. Design based on St.Peter's Cathedral in Rome a truly breathtaking monument built at the beginning of 19th century. Prayers to Mary Mother of God of Kazan believed to have helped conquer Napoleon in 1812. Beautifully restored after a stormy history in communist times. A MUST while in St.Petersburg.

One of a kind and magnificent Orthodox cathedral. Grand and very religious. It doesn't look like a cathedral from the outside. There are ongoing Orthodox religious processions for you to experience the atmosphere. It is one of the larget cathedrals in St. Pet. It resemble St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City. The cathedral is the monument to glory of Russian arms. The famous Russian Field Marshal Mikhail Kutuzov, who won the most important campaign of 1812 against Napoleon was buried inside the Kazan Cathedral.

Grand church!. Kazan church was very near the apartment I stayed in Nevsky Prospekt and we were very impressed by the architecture. Instead of other churches that are museums, Kazan church is a functioning church with worshippers coming in droves. Everything here is done in grand scale and there is a long line of people to see the icon of Madonna. It has a very powerful vibe and when we were there, a wedding was taking place so we got to hear the accoustics of the place which was amazing. If you're on Nevsky prospekt drop by for a while and see the granduer of this beautiful and serene church.

Worth a short visit. Very cool cathedral in the middle of the city close to other attractions. It is free to visit and much less of a tourist atmosphere than Isaac's or Spilled Blood. Here it is quiet and there are services going on every day, so you should be quiet and respectful while inside. But it is very beautiful inside and has a different feeling because it is less of just a museum.

Very impressive Cathedral.. We were staying quite close to this Cathedral and visited it on a few occasions. It has a very attractive interior with beautiful icons and altar. It also contains historical artefacts from the Napoleonic wars.

A stunning free must see .. This cathedral is free to enter. It's situated just set off Nevsky prospect. The beautiful artwork and architecture is amazing. I noticed nearly all the women had a headscarf to cover their head , so it might be worth bringing one with you .
Impressive Cathedral. Easy to get to along Nevsky Pr. Part of the outside is under of construction but if you are there well worth going in for a visit.

Another 18th /19th century Russian Orthodox Church. It is also known as Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan and falls under the category of Russian Orthodox Church. It resembles St Peter's Basilica in Vatican City (Rome). Late in 19th century this Church also became the Centre of first political meeting. It would not be out of place to mention that today its the Mother Cathedral in St. Petersburg. I have been to Rome, Florence and Vatican and I find the architecture, doors and columns of this Church very much similar to the Cathedrals in those cities.
impressive. One of the most impressive church I've ever seen, enormous pillars and those floor tiles! Also the outside is awesome, so incredibly big!

Under Restoration. Visited after The Hermitage museum. A lot of walking but not a lot to see at the Kazan as it was closed for restorations. Looked like a massive cleaning project had been carried out. You can obviously see the cleaned and the uncleaned parts of the cathedral.

A living beatiful church. Entrance: Free
Ambience: A lot
A live church: Yes (a wedding was in progress when we visited)
Beatiful: Yes
True to style: Yes
Photography: Not allowed

Nice. Very impressive place to stay most amazingly maintained. Free nice to see
Worth a visit near the center

A must see!. In this cathedral there is a very highly revered Orthodox icon - Our Lady of Kazan, and the tomb of a Russian general as revered - Mihail Kutuzov. Like all Russian cathedrals and this is very big with beautiful icons.Interestingly that this Orthodox cathedral resembles the shape of St Peter church in Rome.

Question about outside; is this a churge?. This is a special building. From the outside one can hardly see that this is a church. Inside it is large, but not very special. The church is located close / next to the Nevski Prospect.

atmosphere!!!. at first I thought: 'oh well, just another orthodox church of splendour'. but already by entering I noticed it's different. even though it's a huge building one feels comfortable and some warmth. while I was in there a wedding took place. this wonderful mix of parishers, tourists and guests of the wedding gave the hall a special atmosphere. very respectful. this ceremony was wonderful. and obviously everyone inside kazan cathedral thought so, cause most were facing the ceremony. afterwards I walked around in the cathedral that bares orthodox art in many designs.

A good cathedral styled in lines of the Vatican. It is styled like the vatican. When i went, renovation work was happening on the exteriors so I could not get good pictures. But inside, it is quite calm and peaceful. It has a free entry and is not crowded with tourists.
Well worth a visit.. Well worth a stroll through this cathedral. Some stunning Russian iconography and a beautiful building.

Huge colonnades, huge church. Built in a western style with paintings of holy people, not the usual Russian church with frescoes adorning walls.The miracle icon of Our Lady of Kazan has a huge line of people to venerate it. Very quite and cool atmosphere

St Petersburg's most important church. Quite a dramatic exterior but not the most imposing I felt. I've seen my fare share of churches and cathedrals this trip so perhaps I have church fatigue. Still, interior does have some nice pieces; the golden sun symbol is quite startling. No photos as usual inside but a 15 mins walk about inside will allow you to see everything.
interesting architecture. Impressive architecture. Interesting inside. It's a dhame you can't take photo's but on the other hand also understandable.

Kazan. Free entrance as far as i remember. Photos not authorized inside.
allow about 30 minutes to enjoy this beautiful cathedral.

Historical place. Nothing so much. Always has activities inside. People go in and out the whole day.
Around the area quite dirty

Huge....Outstanding Cathedral!. Centrally located, about 7-10 minute walk before getting to the Chrst of the Spilled Blood Cathedral, and by Nevsky Prospect street (one of the main streets in St. Petersburg), the structure of this Church is monumental! I got in by a door on the left side, and as soon as I was inside I felt deeply in awe of the beautifullness of the icons and paintings, marvelous chandeliers....and the people...quietly and respectfully making line for kissing The Beloved Mother Mry....women still wearing scarfs to cover their heads....Solemn ! ......Moving experience! .....Highly recommended Cathedral to visit!

Authentic and Unique Cathedral. This Cathedral near Metro Station at Nevsky Prospect, jump from the metro station turn right and around 200 meters you will find this. The take photography session will be great at evening, cause the sunlight will shine over the dome. maybe you can enter this cathedral, when i came there the cathedral have ceremoby so close for the public, the garden in front of Cathedral is very beautiful

Kazan Cathedral St Petersburg. Lovely colonnaded exterior, does not really look like a cathedral from the outside. The interior is lovely, lots of icons and lovely altar. You are not supposed to take photos though lots where.

Try to go while the choir is singing. Indeed is a very beautiful building but not so different from any other orthodox Russian church. If you are already in the center it is worth a visit. Nevertheless if you plan to go there, make sure to go while they are having service and the choir is singing, them you have the perfect scenario to see and learn more about the traditions.
Majestic . I was not at all impressed with the st-peters knock off but so many people told us to go so I did. The inside is beautiful! A must see
Beautifull. I prefer it at night because it is lighted and you can make great photos of it from the Nevsky avenue.

Nice attraction. Very impressive church both from the outside and the inside. Right on Nevskiy avenue, worth visiting while strollinng on St. Petersburg most touristic road. Very well lighted at night as well.

Piece of history. I middle of Newsky propect and in heart of city...beatifull old building at the moment under reconscruction,small park in front of it and opposite one of the most beatifull newsky building cafe singer,also opposite this popular canal with blood church.

Very Beautiful Cathedral in Central Location. This is a grand church, built in the style of St. Peter's in Rome. It has a most important icon to Our Lady of Kazan, venerated by Russian Orthodox worshippers. You will see long queues of folks waiting to pray at the icon. It has a most beautiful interior with many details, paintings and sculptures. You can easily visit without charge and may take photos discretely. It is very centrally located, across Nevsky Prospekt from the beautiful Singer building that has the very large bookshop, Dom Knigi. This is very much worth a visit to see the interior.
Make sure to visit. Be sure to head to the top and enjoy the view of the city.The orthodox Cathedral is found in the central city and easily accessible
Free Entrance. It is one of the old Cathedral and on the main road and very close to Metro stn.inside is very huge and very well decorated. Being a Sunday we could watch some programme.

Very Beautiful Orthodox Cathedral in St. Petersburg!. Kazan Cathedral is the mother cathedral of the metropolis of St. Petersburg! Both exterior and interior are decorated with numerous columns. The interior is also decorated with spectacular sculptures and icons. One of the most beautiful cathedrals of St. Petersburg!

Kazan Cathedral. There is no entrance fee . The place is an orthodox church . Picture taking inside is not allowed . Inside are lines of worshipper before the image of the VIrgin Mary . Outside the cathedral are seats where one can use to relax .

Divine place. great cathedral .one will sure feel blessed when entering the holy place.must be visited location is easy to reach.all buses& trams stop infront of the cathedral .photography is not allowed inside the cathedral.
Centrally located historic Cathedral. Easily accessed central Cathedral, built in the spirit of Russian Cathedrals ,large and amazing!! No entrance fee.Well worth a visit !!
Too stunning . Too stunning place and great and amazing sightseeing near nevski st .besid singer bulding also with blood savior view

A working cathedral. It is a working cathedral of orthodox church in Nevskey Prospect.Enterance is free.when we went a service was going on and hence could attend an orthodox service which is a lot different to an anglican one.
Great. Photos don't reflect the size and beauty of it at all. When you are entering the cathedral you feel so small, amazing architecture, blown away.

Impressive. Very grand on the outside and, with its looks, you can imagine it as a parliamentary or congress building. Needs a bit of love and attention to the exterior but still a dominating sight. Inside is expansive but a lot darker than many other churches we visited. We dropped in twice and both times there was a form of religious service happening. Very much a working church.

Incredible Iconograpy. We happened to visit while a wedding was in progress, making the experience somewhat mystical. Beautiful icons and hundreds of candles throughout the cathedral make it the perfect sanctuary for an escape from the bustle of Nevsky Prospect.

Beautiful. Unlike Saviour on spilled blood, or St. Isaac's, its a fully functioning, beautiful cathedral. Feels a bit odd to be walking and staring when people around you are praying. But a beautiful building nonetheless

Impressive and symmetrical. Impressive building, I only checked it out from the outside. There's a small park in front of it with benches and fountains, inviting visitors to rest and contemplate. it's right at the busy nevsky prospekt, so it's not the quietest place.

Solemn. The outside looks quite severe and powerful, based on St Peter's, but given a military overtone to fit the early 19th century wars, but inside it is stunning to see hundreds of people, mainly women, worshipping at particular paintings, making the sign of the cross and kissing the portrait, lighting candles, and having a long queue to pray at the Our Lady of Kazan icon. The church itself is not as colourful on the inside as many churches, but makes up for this by being a living, breathing church full of worshippers. Quite humbling.

OUR FIRST STOP IN ST. PETERSBURG. We only saw from the outside but very impressive to see. Next trip we will go inside but we had so much planned this 3-day shore excursion we were happy to just see the outside of Kazan.

"The most....". Do not be misled into thinking that this epithet could "be skipped" for something you see in St Petersburg! One way or another, you will see only what is "the most" here :)If you do not like "an attraction" from one side, just circle it around! This time you will see "the most" refined and delicate bars from cast iron - Voronikhin's Bar which is by its perfect proportions and 'lace' appearance is attributed to the pearls of High Classicism! Enjoy!

Grand!. What an amazing building. Kazan looks very impressive from the outside, and it is equally impressive on the inside. There is something special about being in a Cathedral that is full of local women in scarves doing "their thing", honouring saints, adoring the Madonna, lighting candles, praying in the dimly lit interior. Beautiful. Women should wear a scarf over their head. Take one in your bag for all cathedrals and churches,

Impressive cathedral complex on the main street. Kazan Cathedral has a very impressive front gallery with 2 arms of very big granite colonades that envelope the front garden. The columns continues inside the cathedral. The inside is also very nice with lots of gilded work, paintings, etc. I particularly like the big gilden sun over the door into the inner sanctum. Since there are so many nice cathedral, I would say the unique thing about Kazan really is the colonades outside.

Not as Beautiful as the Others. this is a church and not a museum. Live service was in progress while we were there. It is a magnificent structure, just not as ornate and as beautiful as the others. Save this for last if you have limited time.

Large Simple Beautiful Place Of Worship. Would recommend visiting Kazan Cathedral to get a glimpse of the Russian faithful. Not over the top in decor which is refreshing. Projects a calm serene energy. Not over run by large groups and has free admission. Simply beautiful.

Meaning church. This is a beautiful church but also of great significance to the Russian people. Most of the Eastern Orthodox churches in Russia require women to wear a head cover and this one is no different. There is a beautiful rose garden in front.

Grand. This is a grand cathedral just out side the metro station. Very easy access and once inside it is quiet and grand. The front of the cathedral is behind an arch of huge columns that belie the fact that right behind this is a huge cathedral.The insides have beautiful stained glass windows and so many artifacts that one looses focus.The prayer are is separate and so tourists can move around.

Vatican Copy..... Another Kazan Cathedral (one of the most venerated icon within the Russian Culture), this in particular was design by Voronikhin as a copy of St. Peters Basilica in the Vatican. Consider as an offense by many while it was constructed, it was finalized in the capital of the Empire at the time, in what it was a show of opulence. As a symbol, the Kazan Cathedral was involve in even the Napoleonic wars and was the place of the first political Demonstration in Russia. With different uses during a long period of time, now a days serves a Cathedral since 1992, when it was returned to the Russian Orthodox Church. An interesting place to visit....

Beautiful Cathedral. We visited the Orthodox Kazan Cathedral on a Sunday afternoon. The faithful waited in a long line to kiss the holy relic, the Icon of Our Lady of Kazan. The icon was discovered in a tunnel under the city of Kazan and distributed to Russian cities. The relic here was missing for many years. Even though it is a replica it is venerated none the less. The interior of the church is dim with dazzling gold and silver. The exterior with its long curving portico and columns resembles St. Pete's in Rome. There is a lovely park with a water fountain in front of the church. On this sunny afternoon, it was a great place to people watch.

A church, not a museum. It was a privilege to be able to witness an Orthodox service and to see the people lining up to kiss the icon. A different slice of life in this very touristy part of the city.

St. Petersburg City Highlight!. Located on the main Nevsky prospect, it is convenient to visit either by the Metro or by taking a bus which stops right in front of the Cathedral. Very impressive colonnade! Reminded me of a Court of Justice or the Vatican City, though on a much smaller scale. Interior was a little dark. Attraction within is to get to kiss the icon of Our lady of Kazan. One may have to queue up to do this. The Cathedral closes at about 8 p.m. so you can make it the last on your itinerary for the day.
Great Cathedral. Great Cathedral where you can see a lot of locals going there to pray. This is one of more others churches what you can enjoy in Petersburg.

One of the most beautiful places. To call it the best place in St. Petersburg is an overstatement. Every 500 m, you come across a monument or a church or a square and you forget which one is the best.Nevertheless, this cathedral is beautiful and if you enter the Singer Building (the VKONTAKT hq is on the 5th, 6th and 7th floor while the cafe is on rhe 2nd) you will not be disappointed with the view.

Not special. Visit this when you're nearby and have plenty of time to loose.when not, stay away. There's much more interesting churches in St Petersburg than this one. The place could also use some restauration works

Well worth a visit. This beautiful Cathedral had many beautiful stained glass windows and lavish decoration. A special place of peace used by many genuine worshipers.
Victor over Napoleon. The Cathedral has a large statue of Kuznetzov outside and a well-tended grave inside.It is a working church and most worshippers have come to see the Icon of Our Lady of Kazan.

Another Gem. Kazan cathedral is another of St Pete's religious gems. Based on the design of St Peter's in Rome this church is another feast for the senses. visit in eastern april 2015. i visit in time of ceremony . it is nice clean , inside with some shopping buffets and nice pictures

great ortodox ceremony. by chance we stumled on an ortodox religious ceremony, my first, very impressive, especially the chorals, at both ends of the church simultaneously. otherwise church is more impressive from the outside

Fabulous cathedral!. Kazanskiy Kafedralniy Sobor (Kazan Cathedral), also known as the Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan is one of the largest churches in St. Petersburg. Here, the famous Russian Field Marshal Mikhail Illarionovich Kutuzov himself is interred. Built in 1801-1811 by architect A. Voronikhin, the cathedral is consecrated to the miraculous icon of Our Lady of Kazan. In 1932, the cathedral turned into a museum of the history of religion. Since 1991, services were resumed and from 2000, the cathedral returned to the Russian Orthodox church and was ascribed to the eparchy of St. Petersburg. Emperor Paul wanted the cathedral to resemble the St. Peter's cathedral basilica in Rome. To achieve the demands, a tremendous colonnade consisting of 96 columns was erected in front of the northern facade.

Interesting and larger than it looks from outside. An interesting Cathedral with a different design. It is modeled on the St Peters Basilica in Rome so has a familiar look about it. It is far larger than it looks from it's exterior when viewed from Nevsky Prospekt.It is still a working church today and a focus for worship by many Russians as it is also partly seen as a memorial to the Russian victory over Napoleon.It is dedicated to Our Lady of Kazan, one of the holiest icons in Russia.Visited February 2013

Wonderful. On Nevsky Prospect and easy to get to but definitely worth a visit as you stroll up the street. It doesn't really look like a cathedral from the out side but inside it definitely is. Beautifully decorated and quite impressive.

Imposing. I cannot tell you precisely why I find this cathedral ugly, but it is at least ugly in a somewhat interesting way. It is worth a stop inside. Lovely. Very impressive both inside and out. The interior is especially wonderful and we were lucky enough to be there for a service which added to the enjoyment.

Old world. Absolutely vast building and incredible inside, the air is thick with incense and there are icons everywhere which people will queue infront of to say their prayers to and also to kiss. Photos are allowed although not with flash. There is a gift shop which sells lovely trinkets and although nobody tells you to, its expected that you should cover your head out of respect.
A symbol of petersburg. It is a huge building and a must visit place. Inside is like a church and there is no entrance fee. There is religious practice at nights.

Large and Grand on a Grand Street. This huge fronted Cathedral makes a strong statement as is resides Predominantly on Nevsky Prospect. Externally and internally it is worth visiting and consuming. After way too many decades of neglect it wasn't til the mid 90's that this building started to come back to life.
