The Roman Orthodox Church. The main entrance of this early 19th Cent. Orthodox Cathedral occupies an impressive situation in the city’s main street, Nevsky Prospekt. You would be hard pressed to recognize it as an Orthodox structure, as it has only a single enormous dome without any of the traditional onion skin decorations, and is flanked on both sides by an extensive colonnade. This ambivalence stems from the curious paradox that its design was inspired by that of St. Peter’s in Rome, and can be construed as an ecumenical gesture towards the Roman Catholic Church aimed at improving relations between the two great early branches of Christianity. Unlike its Roman model, the area in front is covered by a well manicured lawn that includes a single vertical fountain. Not only Rome, but Florence also managed to get involved in the complimentary plagiarism, since the large doors of the Cathedral imitate those that Ghiberti created for the Florence Baptistery. The interior has much more to tell us about Russian history, as it was completed only a year before Napoleon’s invasion, and his nemesis ---- Field-Marshall Kutuzov ----- is buried within. He is reputed to have dedicated his ultimate victory to Our Lady of Kazan, a celebrated icon whose intervention he sought, and that was embedded in the iconostasis of the newly-built Cathedral. The sacristy also contains the keys of many European cities and castles that were conquered by the Russian Army prior to Napoleon’s downfall at Waterloo. The height of the interior is emphasized by the immensity of the dome, and the height of the many pillars within. The church is well endowed with fine works of religious art ---- sculptures and icons ---- produced for the original by some of the greatest Russian craftsmen of the day. After the 1917 Revolution, it suffered the customary fate of conversion to a Museum of Religion and Atheism, and only in 1996 was it returned to the Orthodox Church for public worship. It is now considered to be the Mother Church of St. Petersburg’s Orthodox Community, and as such is certainly well worth while getting to know.

Beautiful building in St P. This was built to rival the Vatican in Rome and looks like it.We were fortunate to see a Russian wedding taking place when we visited. Go with your camera during the day and again at night when it's lit up.

Impressive place. Impressive building and active church, worth a stop on your explorations of the city. Beautiful inside with many mementos of past battles. Some unit standards from the war with Napoleon honoring the general that won the battle.

Stunning. One of the most Beautiful awe inspiring churches in St Petersburg, within easy walk of our hotel. The history attached to it is most interesting and out guide filled us in on all it's details. Do not miss this Cathedral
Just walked around ant it was nice. Just walked around when was on Nevskiy Prospect and it was nice. Never been inside. Seems that it is still working orthodox church.

Stunning building. This cathedral is simply stunning, sitting just back off Nevsky Prospect, right by the metro. Looks good during daylight but simply magnificent by night (have your camera at the ready). Has retained all its ancient charm internally. Worth a browse around if you like these types of buildings as I do.
Kazan Icon worth a visit. Russian Field Marshall Mikhall Kutuzov, who defeated Napolean in 1812 is buried inside. The elegance & simplicity of the interior of the cathedral is quite stunning.
Beautiful. On Nevskiy Prospect, this is well-worth a visit. We were lucky enough to be there when a service was taking place. The singing was out of this world...

Worth a visit. It's a church that people still line up to kiss the portrait!
From outside, the architecture resembles St. Peters in Rome, in a much smaller scale of course.
Inside, a beautiful church glistering in gold, covered with paintings and a soaring dome.
Absolutely worth a visit if you are into architecture, and it's free.

Impressive building. This building is one of the most impressive ones in St. Petersburg. You can't miss it because it is alongside Nevsky avenue.Although it seems big, the Cathedral itself is small (relatively speaking).Go there in the morning when there is a mass between 9 and 10am. You will see how they celebrate it. Very powerful choir and people standing all the time. There is a lot of movement inside and it is very beautifully decorated.Free entrance but no pictures allowed.Woman must wear a scarf on their head and men without hat.I like it very much.

imposing on the outside, a gem on the inside. Centrally located near the Nevskiy Prospect shops, hotels and restaurants. I bustled past it several times before venturing in, Glad I did - it was an unexpected treasure.

Loved It!. It looks intimidating from the outside with it's massive pillars forming a colonnaded crescent. As you wonder through the doors of this Russian Orthodox Cathedral you will be captivated by it's magnificence. It's a working church so there will be locals going about their daily rituals and prayers. Highly recommended!

Great place. We stayed about a minute away from here and so passed it every day intending on going in on our last day which we did. From the outside it looks big, ok, nothing too special - and then you get inside. No fee. It was just great. I stayed a while inside looking at all the different areas and the roof etc. It really was fantastic. Husband was told to go outside as he only had a singlet on so had to wait for me for a while as I could not get enough. Def recommend going here.
Lovely Cathedral. This is a working orthodox cathedral and has a very nice interior. It is free entry and I would recommend a visit.

Beautiful cathedral. The Kazan Cathedral is amazingly beautiful. An orthodox church which from the outside looks more like a museum, but once inside you forget what the exterior looks like. Everywhere you look, every inch is a piece of art. I enjoyed watching the locals partake in their prayers and rituals around the cathedral, especially a picture of Kazan herself. People queue for over 20 minutes to pray and kiss the picture of "Our Lady of Kazan". Such an amazing sight.

very nice.. Kazan's cathedral located on the main avenu Nevskiy prospect and Griboedov canal.In the USSR time was ateism museum.Present moment orthodox church.It is very beautiful architecture .front of cathedral nice lilac's trees blooming on the spring.Across street bigest and oldest Books House.
Beautiful and breath taking. Very remarkable church and amazing architecture. There is no fee for entrance and walking around inside was well worth visiting!

Still functioning Russian Orthodox Cathedral. No photographs are allowed since this is a still functioning cathedral. The many icons on display were very interesting and the feeling inside is very serene. Many Orthodox pilgrimage to this cathedral to pray to a famous icon.
Kazan. The outside is very interesting. Doesn't really look like a church. This Russian Orthodox Church has an amazing altar. Full of silver where most are in gold. The icons are great.

An extraordinary cathedral to feel the spirit of religion. From the outside I never guesses what was waiting for me inside. The beauty of the cathedral with so many people praying in front of different icons was overwhelming me. It was just entering a different world and feeling the spirit of the praers. The interior is beautifuk, the size is stunning and the athmosphere was really catching me. Take your time and you won't regret it.
impressive. we visited on a Saturday and a service was taking place in one corner of this big cathedral....so wonderful to stand quietly and have an insight into another faith and their way of life.

An actual working Cathedral. St. Isaac Cathedral is not a place of worship. It is a museum. Our Lady of Kazan is a worshipful church. There are many who are in the cathedral to only worship or pray in front of an icon. The outside of the cathedral does not prepare you for the beauty within. I sat for half and hour to pray and could feel the prayers of people who have prayed there for the last couple hundred years. The beauty of the interior and the worshipful atmosphere make this extraordinary church a must visit.

Another fantastic church. Reminding a bit of St. Peter's Church in Rome, the Kazan offers a wonderful exteriour as well as an impressive inside. It was an ongoing service while we were there so couldn't walk freely around, however we got a very good impression of the grandeur of this place.

Can't miss the Kazan Cathedral. There's plenty of big buildings to see in St Petersburg, and the Kazan Cathedral is another one not to miss. it's also a great landmark to use as a meeting point if you are all shopping in different directions on the Nevsky Prospect. Our shuttle bus left from just behind the Kazan Cathedral

Another stunning site in St. Petersburg. We made a quick stop in this cathedral at the end of our visit. It is stunning inside. It definitely is worth a much longer visit. Lots to see and absorb. Long line of pilgrims to visit a relic that is located here. This will be on my list of must -sees for my next visit.

Magnificent and Majestic Cathedral. It's very stunning, magnificent and majestic cathedral especially their neoclassic style architect. I don't see a lot of cathedral designing like this place in St. Petersburg.

Try and catch a Russian Orthodox service. We went in early in the morning on a weekday and there was a service going on, there were several clergymen with banners doing the stations of the cross followed by a steady stream of old women with headscarves. For anyone who hasn't seen a Russian Orthodox service, its well worth going to. All of it sung, when the priests aren't singing the parishioners do and when neither of them are, there is a choir in the eves singing. The Cathedral itself is great, there is a special place received fro the Romanovs and their paintings are on the walls. As the church celebrates the defeat of Napoleon at Borodino their are several French battle standards on display which would be of great interest to anyone interested in history or literature. The emphasis on the victory is heightened by the approach into the Cathedral which is flanked on either side by (I think) large statues of Kutuzov and De Tolly. Its certainly worth a pop in!

Atypical. Free. Atypical architecture. The part located on the main street (Nevsky Prospekt) is actually the back of the cathedral. Entrance is free. You can take pictures inside. It contains the mostf venerate icon of Russia. Long queues are formed to kiss the icon.

atmospheric and remarkable. If the Orthodox religion wishes to emhasize atmosphere over intellect, it achieves this is spades. Piety and aesthetics meet here. The queue for those kissing the icon was very impressive

Fascinating View of the Russian Soul. This church isn't the quintessential onion dome church. It has a Roman colonnade in front and doesn't fit our western idea of a Russian church. However, this is a true working church and is not attempting to cater to tourists. Be respectful. Don't take photographs. You will see a true place of worship. Try to understand the long lines of people waiting to kiss the icon of Our Lady of Kazan and what it means to them. See the hundreds of candles lit in front of the icons. This was all very different from my western religious experience, and gave me a fascinating glimpse of something very different. Appreciate it, but don't intrude.

Well worth a visit!. Incredible curving double colonnade facade, on a mighty scale frets your first look from the Nevskij Prospect. The interior is equally grandiose and sombre in tone compared to other places of worship in SP and well worth a visit.

You'll walk past it for sure. Take a photo of the facade and you're set.. You'll pass by it for sure as you walk around the Nevsky Prospect to feel the rhythm of the city. Is it particularly worth exploring? No, not really. But it's a marvellous view of the facade and the Kutuzov statue from the outside and you'll definitely get a photo there. Still, probably best keep walking past and dedicate more time to Saviour on Spilled Blood.
Beautiful church. This is an active church and a service was in progress when we visited. Out of respect we didn't take photos. Again a beautiful church.

Accessible. This is a most accessible cathedral, being on Nevskiy Prospect. Parts of the cathedral are roped off for people worshiping. There is a palpable reverence as many people go about their religious rituals. Could be a good idea to carry a small scarf if you intend visiting.Interesting that there are photos of the interior posted on Trip Advisor when there are clear signs on the doors saying no photos!! This also seems disrespectful while in a 'working church'.

A Must See!. The Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan is a definite must see when in St. Petersburg. The interior is beautiful and it's moving to see many locals coming to pray before the miraculous icon of Our Lady of Kazan. There's also a large icon devoted to the last imperial family and the grave of Marshall Kutuzov who helped defeat Napoleon. Unlike the other large cathedrals in the city, this one is a working house of worship and so one gets a feel for the beauty of the rituals of the Russian Orthodox church and the devotion of the locals. Also, be sure to check out the icons being sold, they are very reasonably priced. All in all, highly recommended!

Very nice.. Located right on the main street of St. Petersburg. It's very beatifull and you can have nice pictures there. During the summer it's a very nice place to spend few hours with your friends. We loved it.
special. This cathedral has a unique architecture ,and inside you will find some magnificent master pieces,I highly recommend visiting this place from inside and out.
Spiritual experince. We attended the 7h00 service on the Sunday morning. The choir members stand as part of the congregation and they sing beautifully. Well worth it.
Excellent!. The collonade, the statues of Kutuzov and Barclay de Tolly, and the beautiful church bearing the name of Russia's holiest (lost) icon, this site is must see in St. Petersburg!

This is the real deal. As practicing Catholics we felt fine at the Russian Orthodox service. It is a bit like the reverence of Latin services from long ago. It is VERY poor taste to talk during a service and some tourist children were playing loudly with the candles which was disrespectful but fortunately they got bored and left. There is a great sense of loyalty, devotion and faith which is palpable.

beautiful. when you think about Russian cathedrals you imagine colored Stupas ,....but when you face with Kazan cathedral you find it too different . it was more like as a historical victory monument . inside was like as other famous church's and cathedrals , too beautiful and too spiritual.

saw a wedding!!!. A cathedral with history and ambience. It was a strange experience I was viewing it as a tourist but a wedding was being conducted which felt an immense privilege to witness and something i will always remember. there is also a cathedral cat ther that looks like hitler!
Ordinary. I think It's ordinary and plagiarised from Italy. I think Italy has better ones. But I went there, because it's quite near the city center...

A must. Amazing Church. In the morning there is a service and a choir of men. Fantastic. in the afternoon a long line to kiss the icon of our Lady of Kazan. Amazing.And even better, the modestly decorated grave of Field Marshal Kutuzov, the hero of the 1812 War against Napoleon. French flags caught during the offensive against the invading French decorate the grave.

Great Visit!. The outside of this cathedral was more beautiful of the outside and it is located on the best street (Nevskiy) for sightseeing. We were in St. Petersburg on the Day of our Lady Kazan so this place was busy! Right across the street from the Zinger Building which holds a huge book store and café. One of my favorite restaurants, La Taressa, overlooks this cathedral.

Peaceful and quiet. Despite there are many people inside the church, it was very quiet as it still function as a church rather than a museum. I think it is worth to take a look as it is one of the key churches in St. Petersburg.

Peaceful. There are many striking buildings in this city, none more so than the cathedral, it features in the television transmissions on the Russian Christmas Eve celebrations alongside the naval cathedral on Krondstadt and has a certain noble quality that makes it good to look at.Obviously it is a venerated building with many people coming to pray and to pay respect to whichever icon they perceive to be the most holy, although can's say I would fancy kissing the same spot on a wood framed glass cabinet as the other hundreds of lips!If you want to get a clear and panoramic view then take coffee in the Singer building opposite at first floor level (that's the second in Russia) and the sweeping wings and columns will have your eyes in awe, it really does look a well balanced and cared for place. No doubt others can give you an insight as to its uses during the first stages of the "lovely" Soviet period, what a bunch.Inside there is peace and an air of quiet contemplation, the smell of candle wax and incense, a quietness that is the exact opposite of what is happening on Nevsky. Although, only here could you get two guys carrying a makeshift structure in wood about 20 feet long and the crowd of visitors just part as though its a portable icon.The decorations, actual bas relief and painting is very well designed and restored, not too much gold and very muted colours, many icons beautiful columns and floors.Take some time to sit and look, respect the traditions, ladies to cover their heads and legs, no hats etc. many people here appear to have genuine affinity to the Orthodox Church which is a nice counterbalance to the mayhem outside.

Worth a look. There are lots of Orthodox churches to see in St P's but this Cathedral has some interesting art to compliment its vast space and history. There was a service being conducted at one end whilst we were there which gave us an insight to the Russian religion. Across the road is a famous bookshop and cafe on the second floor which gives you a great view whilst having a coffee.

Incredible colums supporting a beautiful church. The outside was like a mini St Peter's Square in Rome with the columns on either side of the church in the same style. Inside was amazing, with massive columns supporting the structure. It was beautifully decorated and has an icon which appears to be a 'mecca' to church goers, queuing for hours to pay homage and kiss it. I was very taken by the architecture of this church, probably more so than by it's actual beauty.
Russian Orthodox Church. Impressive amount of gold around and lots of interesting old icons. Huge church with porticoed arms.

Bring binoculars. The church is lovely. The now-famous art is behind a rope that kept us about 20 feet away so that to me it looked like a flat black panel. So bring binoculars to see it. We had 3x opera glasses and it really helped.
Beautiful active church. This church is really beautiful and is an active church , its very Russian typical, great experience

Dark, vast, and inspiring during a service. We came into the Cathedral during a service, with beautiful music and an ornate display of the treasures of the Cathedral. We appreciated their accommodation to respectful visitors at that time. The Cathedral itself is vast, and it seems darker than other churches we visited.

Magnificent edifice definitely worth visiting. Even if you are tired of Russian Orthodox churches as a result of having seen so many during a trip through Russia, this one is important and should not be missed. It houses two very significant things: first, one of the most revered copies of the icon of Our Lady of Kazan; and second; the grave of the great Russian general Mikhail Kutuzhov, hero of the War of 1812 and a central figure in Tolstoy's epic War and Peace.The Icon of Our Lady of Kazan has been appealed to over and over again in Russian history, particularly in times of war. Allegedly, it was even used by Soviet authorities out of desperation, who reportedly used it in processions around Leningrad fortifications during the lengthy siege of that city. There were even rumors Stalin was so desperate during Hitler's invasion of Russia that he had it brought to Moscow, where atheist Soviet officials paraded it around the Kremlin Walls.General Kutuzhov is the man who ordered the retreat from and evacuation of Moscow in the face of Napoleon's Grand Army, with the intent to lure the French into the empty city as Winter approached –– while the Russian Army recuperated and prepared to harass the French once they were forced to retreat back to France through the horrific Russian Winter. Kutuzhov was obviously successful in his gigantic gamble. His grave is not ostentatious, and even easy to miss. It's worth seeing. The captured banners of the French Army are on display, as well as the keys of the Russian Cities that Napoleon waited in vain to receive while he aimlessly waited in Moscow through the Autumn months.We enjoyed our visit to this Cathedral very much, particularly since we were unaware that either of these treasures was housed here, and were pleasantly surprised and excited to discover them.

Really interesting cathedral to visit. We visited most of the main cathedrals in St Petersburg during our five-day visit. This isn't the most showy, but it's great if you want to get a sense of the Russian Orthodox church and some of its differences from Catholicism (no statues or stained glass, just icons, no seats, etc). We were really grateful to have an excellent guide showing us round though: there is some information in English but it was so much better having someone to explain what we were seeing. And the Kazan Cathedral is nothing like as crowded as the Church on Spilled Blood, or St Isaac's or the St Peter and St Paul Cathedral, which is a big plus - few huge tour groups following their guides around. It's hard to get a good photograph of the cathedral though. The best is probably from the far side of the rose garden in front of it, facing onto Nevsky Prospekt.

Something authentic. WHY WORTH A VISIT: of all the main Russian orthdox churches in St Petersburg, this is the only working church, not a museum. So here your impression of the place will not be ruines by numerous cameras flashing, lound talking and crowds. It's decorated with different kinds of marble and granit, and all the granit is local. Last but not the least, it's the home of the miraculour icon of "Our Lady of Kazan".HOW TO GET THERE: it's not hard at all, as the church is located in the middle of Nevsky prospect, across the street from "Dom Knigi" (former Singer sawing machine store). It's walkable from most hotels in the center, but if you take the metro, the station is called "Nevsky prospekt/ Gorstiny Dvor" and the exit you need is "Kanal Griboedova".BEST TIME TO GO: Around 10AM or 6PM, which is when the mass takes place. PLEASE NOTE:- As it is a working church, be respectful. Don't talk too loud and don't take pictures inside. It's preferable that ladies cover their heads and gents take their hats off. Try not to wear really short skirts or shorts. - The church has some space closer to the altar, which is separated with a rope and a sign "only for the prayers". It means that it's for the people who actually want to listen to the servise and pray. It doesn't mean that tourists are not allowed in. If you really want to participate, just prepare for it. If you are a female visitor, cover your head with a scarf or something and wear pants or a long skirt. Male visitors should take off their hats. You will see that the priest sings a prayer and from time to time everybody makes some gestures with their hands. Try to repeat after them.- You don't have to stay during the mass. Everybody is always free to leave whenever they want. Try to wander around and discover all sorts of little icons hidden in the corners. If you have some rubles, you can buy candles, light them and place them in front of icons as you pray.MUST SEE:- The miraculous icon of Pur Lady of Kazan in the center of the altar wall. You'll recognise it because there will be a line of people waiting to come closer to it and kiss it.-In the corner behind the kiosk you'll see some flags and a memorial space. It's actually a burial place of a Russian field marshal from the war with Napoleon - Kutuzov. The flags you see are rwal French banners and there are also keys from different French towns conquered by Russians.- In the opposite corners look up a little bit and you will see a balcony for the quire. It's not allowed to play musical instruments in orthodox churches, so that's the only source of spiritual music.
An impressive cathedral. The interior is very ornate.We were very lucky to visit the cathedral while there was a wedding in progress.
Surprise!. heard about it - but didn't meant o go. saw it by surprise and went over there just to take some photos - finaly stayed for over 2 hours.recommended!!!

Beautiful cathedral. Huge cathedral with free entrance. Beautiful, awe-inspiring exterior, with a simpler interior, though in no way unimpressive. Still an active place of worship though, so be considerate when visiting!

Magical. The small entrance almost lead to the fact that we almost missed this church. But I'm glad we did see it. It was magical inside. It was really dark and people were singing en queuing to pray to the icon of the Lady of Kazan.
Not high on the list. A functioning church, looks better on the outside than inside. The other churches in town are much better.

Very spiritual and beautiful. Unlike the church of the Spilled Blood and St. Isaac's cathedral, this is a working Russian Orthodox cathedral and not a museum. As such, it is free to visit (although there is box for donations but this isn't pushed), there is no photography within the church and the ladies are encouraged to cover their heads. There is a real spiritual feeling inside the cathedral. I happened on a service which was very special. There are a few seats around to rest and reflect on the cathedral. This was one place that I visited that wasn't full of tours from the cruise ships, just ordinary Russian people paying their respects to the icon. Well worth a visit.

A 15 minute visit. It doesn't take more than 15 minutes to visit this cathedral and it's definitely worth it. With no entry fee and located on the Nevsky Prospect, the cathedral on the outside is a colonnade with a garden in between. Since its a functioning church, it will be difficult to spend a longer time inside as a tourist. No audio guides available.

A spiritual respite. Amid the tourist trappings of St. Petersburg, many of which are great to visit, this church offers a spiritual respite. Note the lines of women in head scarves who await their chance to kiss and pray to the icon of Maria, in the form of Our Lady of Kazan. The place is just dark enough, not glitzy, and you can find icons of saints and prophets to light a candle to if you so desire. Even if you are not a believer, it is one of the only holy places in St. Petersburg and worth visiting in that light.

Must see. This church is in the very middle of the Nevskiy Prospect - can't miss it! It named after an icon of lady of Kasan, that is on the display inside the cathedral - said that this icon saved Leningrad during German occupation of over a year!
Best. St. Petersburg church. Only this cathedral of top ranked attractions is still used for religious purposes.

Very Spiritual Russian Orthodox Cathedral. We were very overwhelmed with the beauty and spirituality of this Orthodox Cathedral. The outside facade does not prepare you for entering into this place of holy worship. A religious mass had just finished along with a small wedding. The interior is dimly lit and along with the smell of the incense, one is transported into a different world.The icon of the Lady of Kazan is a replica of the original, however, the devotion and piety of the worshipers' is fantastic. Mu husband and I were very impressed with the lines of people who come in to "kiss" the image of the icon.The murals and icons are magnificent!

Georgian chanting. Just walked in as hotel very close.... Built as a small replica of St. Peter's in Rome. PLEASE LADIES COVER YOUR HEAD WITH A SCARF. Parishioners fervently worshipping and very reverent public. Live Georgian chanting was like listening to heaven.... What a gift!

A bit like St Paul's Cathedral in Rome. The cathedral is laid out in such a way that it reminds one of St Paul's Cathedral in Rome. Rather austere on the outside and very dirty, The interior is huge but the decoration more subdued and less grandiose than other cathedrals we saw, with the exception of the Altar areas.

Very interesting history. This church has a very interesting history of at one time being an atheist museum. Originally it was a church. Now it is a Russian Orthodox church and quite actively used. We went to enjoy the art. Some of the murals are quite impressive.

Check it out. Surprisingly large inside, nicely decorated and we were fortunate enough to be there when some guys and girls were singing.Couldn't help but think how much cooler it would have been if the Norse gods were the dominant religion at the time of construction vs Mr J and his buddies.

Nice church . It is a very old church but it is not open always I think it was allowed to enter at 6 pm only 2 days maybe Monday is one of them it is located on novosberky street , you have a lot of cafe there to go and sit beside

I expected more.. It seems more a political building (like the Capitol) than a cathedral. Inside is beautiful, but after you see other churches in St. Petersburg, this one is not so impressive. No pictures allowed and you will see at the entrance an advise: "Please, be careful, or become a victim of theft".

The pulsing spiritual heart of a great city. The Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan was described to me by a Russian guide who is a native of St. Petersburg as the "pulsing spiritual heart of the city." I could not agree more. First, it is a magnificent building. The story of how it was used as a "Museum of Atheism" will rend the heart of anyone who values freedom of religion. Its rebirth as a cathedral and parish is a story of people trying to do things right. The cathedral is not only a place of worship but a center for active ministry meeting needs ranging from helping the homeless to feeding the hungry to providing summer respite at a rural dacha for under privileged children. I fell in love with Kazansky.

Our Lady of Kazan. This Church drew us continuously, there is a venerated Icon there and the lines trying to get to touch it were very long. The first day we were there we had the opportunity to hear an Orthodox service which was movin, although we did not understand the words, but just watching the devout people around us was very moving, it made me realize what they had been deprived of for so long.
must-visit place. This church is very beautiful both inside and outside. It is huge. the entrance is free. You can also pay for an excursion.

Imposing & Dismal Exterior But Go Inside. We attended a wedding at the cathedral so we felt privileged to see the iconostasis both closed and open. The space is huge and the acoustics make even a quartet choir or a chanting priest sound magnificent. No photos allowed as this is a working cathedral, which means there's no charge for entry.

A HOLY CHURCH. Reverted from the Museum of Atheism under the Soviets to a fully functioning church & one that it is held in special regard by Russians due to the icon Our Lady of Kazan. It was moving to see the queues waiting to kiss, light a candle & pray in front of the icon.The church also contains a statue of Marshal Kutuzov one of the heroes in Tolstoy's War and Peace. The external half circle of colonnades can not missed as you walk down Nevsky prospect. Certainly worth a visit and afterwards treat yourself to tea & cakes at the Singer House cafe( bookshop on the ground floor).As you enjoy your refreshments you have a fantastic views.

Huge Queue for Lady of Kazan Icon. If you are in St Petersburg you are bound to stroll down Nevskiy Prospekt and this church is in a prominent position so perhaps worth spending ten minutes having a look. Nothing special essentially built to house the Kazan Icon and most people stand in a long queue to view close up. Unless this has a religious significance for you then not worth the time.
Stunning. Visit late in the afternoon to join the locals in prayer. Looking up you are greater by amazing ceilings

Holiness & Sanctity Personified.. On entering the Huge Holy Precints, it is as if you are transported to another world. You have to pull yourself into your shell, block all outside disturbances, to really feel the Sanctity of the place. Tourists do tend to be noisy at times. The Altars are something to see. To me, Our Lady, Is Our Lady of Perpetual Help. You must buy an Icon, as a Memento of your visit.

Worth "Popping In". We liked that most of the people in this Cathedral were Russian. They were in a long queue to touch/kiss an icon. The Cathedral is not a particular "must" but if you are passing it is worth a look inside and does not need to take long.

Ok but really a quick visit. This is a fully operational Russian Orthodox Church and a very Holy Place to worshipers.Visitors are allowed in and it is a very impressive Church but photographs are not openly allowed, It is a place where people's right to worship needs to be respected. As I dont speak Russian I didnt know what was going on and couldnt ask anybody what the visitor protocol was. We enjoyed our visit but as we like to photograph some memories we would not rate it high on your list if time is of the essence.

Must visit in St.Petersburg . This place should be visited by everyone coming to St.Petersburg. It is really historical and one of the most beautiful buildings of the city. You may come inside and see the service or just put a candle. Or just to seat outside and enjoy the beauty of architecture and religion.
very impressive. nothing to say much.very impressive.It is in the center of the city. U pray and thank god to be here
No photos inside. Very decorative, but in use for services - so no photos. Remember ladies must cover their heads. A huge cathedral - it is located off Nevsky Prospekt

marvellous experience!!. Me and my husband went there to see the Kazan church with its Madonna. Wonderfull experience to wait our turn for preying and kissing the Madonna, people from everywhere were here for this magic Madonna... we felt something deep in our soul.

Russian Orthodox Cathedral in NeoClassical Architecture. This cathredral is unique in Russia; while it's not the only Renaissance-style cathedral (St. Issac's is further down the road) it's fairly small and intimate, looking a bit like a jewelbox version of St. Peter's in Rome. Mass is held here regularly and you needn't leave the building if it starts while you're there; in fact you should stay because it's quite a moving experience, even if you're not Orthodox. I had no idea what the ritual protocol was, and actually I felt I had no business trying to follow along, but whenever I was making a faux pas by just standing there--when I was going to be in the way of a procession--one of the elderly ladies would gently touch my arm and move me to the proper place, no scolding or anything. If you're quiet and respectful, they have no problem with you being there. As far as attire, you don't have to be dressed up, but don't look grungy. Men should not wear hats in an Orthodox cathedral, and women should cover their heads (a scarf is typical).

Stunning architecture on Nevsky Prospect. Visited St Petersburg in September 2013. I was out enjoying a tour of the city by foot when I stumbled across this gorgeous architectural maze of colonnades and was simply too dramatic in appearance to resist a visit. This turned out to be Kazan Cathedral which today still functions as an operating church in St Petersburg. Quite refreshing as compared to so many other great churches which are now museums.Great history but then is St Petersburg, a city that literally stretches back hundreds of years. The actual cathedral/church is located at the back of the colonnade so from first inspection you are absolutely unaware that this is a cathedral of any kind. It makes a very easy visit, if you are on Nevsky Prospect just checking out the neighborhood, it is also very close to the Metro which makes it easily accessible.Several viewers commented on their visit during a church service which I did not do. The time I visited was outside of their services but is absolutely worth a walk around - there is no charge to get in and it is a delightful visit.Certainly one of the most impressive architectural buildings in and around the popular tourist sites of St Petersburg.My advice is quite simple - if you are in St Petersburg this is a must visit!

Experience a "working" cathedral in St.Petersburg. Our Lady of Kazan cathedral is one of the few major churches in central St.Petersburg which is a working cathedral rather than a state museum. Architecturally it is quite striking with its dome and huge semi-circular collonade which reaches out to Nevsky Prospect. Much work has been done on it recently and behind it it still looks like a construction site. As a working church, one needs to dress conservitively and photos are not allowed. It is however completely free rather than a couple hundred roubles. The interor is beautiful with scores of icons, mosaics, magnificent iconostases. I would urge visitors to consider comming during services (on Sunday 10 and 1800h) to truly experience it. The music supplied by male choir as well as the priests is unearthly, ancient, dark and deeply spiritual. The smell of incense, hundreds of candles also adds. Just stay quiet, reverent and do what the lady standing next to you is doing and you will have a very special experience even if you can't fully follow what is transpiring or even if you are secular.

Stunning. When one thinks of Russian Cathedrals it is images of St Basil's or Church of the Saviour on the Blood that come to mind. Although those are trully stunning building what makes Kazansky Sobor so fascinating is that it looks completely diferent.Looking more like a palace than a cathedral and placed neatly by Nevsky prospekt this is an easy must-see when visiting Piter!

Church meets world. The beauty of this building keeps a little surprize: A lady in the church constantly is weeping the floor cleaning the wax of the candles brought to the icoon the Holy Mother and child.Seen from the Nevskiy Prospect, you don't see a church in it. But behind this range of colums there is an immense cathedral, repeating the colums inside.

Easy to See. This cathedral is right off the metro on Nevsky Prospekt, so you have no reason why not to visit. and it faces the Church on Spilled Blood, at the end of the canal, another must. This is an actual working cathedral so you can possibly catch a service here if you wish. While is't not a opulent as some of the others, it is right on Nevsky, which makes it an easy target to visit. And when you consider it was a "Museum of the History of Atheism and Religion" during the Soviet period, it makes the visit even more interesting.

Excellent central landmark. When I got out of the metro on Nevskiy Prospekt station on my first day, this was the first thing that caught my eye. I directly went to see it. Looks impressive from outside, and it has this huge entrance like a garden, which has a festive-like atmosphere.It is located right in front of the Nevskiy Prospekt, which made it a place to memorize for me, which helped me find my way during my visit.

loved it!. I have noticed i love cathedrals! Not a big person on actually attending church but do love the cathedrals! I simply loved this one! The way it is shaped catches your eye first. It is not shaped like your normal cathedrals! I would say it is unique. The look from the inside does not disappoint. It is simply breathtaking! Something hits you when you walk in and you feel like you are in a special place. The good thing is this cathedral is right down nevsky with alot of other tourist things so you can't miss it.

Surprising!. This church is enormous with countless icons and art pieces. There were services going on as tourists roamed around, with women covering their hair with scarves looking for solace kissing icons of their chosen saints or the virgin mother. Sitting on a bench and taking it all in was an experience in it self.

WOW. Along Nevsky Prospekt this Cathdral is impressive - facing a fascinating shop with a dome-like top and a short walk along a canal to deliver you to a beautiful domed church, this building stands out along Nevsky.
The risk is to repeat myself. Cathedrals are a must in St. Petersburg and Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan does not make an exception.

Central location. You probably walk past this church in Saint Petersburg, so why not go inside as well? It's free, unlike St. Isaac's Cathedral and Church of Our Savior on Spilled Blood. With some luck, you can even see some real action inside... Don't miss Napoleon's standards inside!

What a change. The main Cathedral for St. Petersburg, this used to be the "Museum of the History of Atheism and Religion" during the Soviet period. Now it is a church again and the main Cathedral for the city. Not necessary to tour, but definitely worth a visit when strolling along Nevsky Prospect. Ladies be sure to wear a head scarf as it is a working church.
Experience an orthodox mass!. Singing mass is beautiful, and it is nice to see people praying to get little understanding about Russian religion and traditions.
Impressive outside. We didnt want to miss the visit, as from the outside it did look very inviting, but again, it was ok, but really nothing special inside the Cathedral.
plain interior, durty exterior. nothing special but free and central, you cannot visit SP and don't pass it at least one, so have a look

Lovely, powerful stop. A beautiful church--I really enjoyed getting to touch and pray by the figure of Lady of Kazan by the altar (despite the long line). The souvenir shop has great treasures. While longer skirts/pants and covered heads (for women) are not obligatory, I'd recommend it as a sign of respect for those who are there to pray.

A beautiful "working" church. Unlike some other churches in St Petersburg this one is used as a church and so is different fro others that have been restored as attractions. There was a young couple getting married while we visited and many devout visitors. Note that non-tourist visitors cover their heads. A lovely old church.

stay for a mass. I am Catholic and when I visited Kazan Cathedral, I am glad I stayed on to hear the mass. Good to see their traditions. The church has lots of icons, paintings and how I wish I had someone explain the religion and introduce the icons to me. Maybe some day, when I return.

Old spirit. It's a church and museum at same time! Some people come here to pray and some to see greatest general who won Napoleon - Mikhail Kutuzov. There are many keys from cities which he has conquered

Not to be missed when you're on Nevinsky Prospekt. We were staying opposite this huge church and so developed a real fondness for it.
The exterior is imposing, and inside dark and equally awesome.

Somber and beautiful. A very interesting place. Women should wear a scarf or a hooded sweatshirt or anything to cover their heads. This is a very serious place for the faithful and it's a bit insulting to go in there without respecting their beliefs.

One of the few free attractions in St Petersburg. Coming from a city where all the state museums are world famous and free, it was a bit of a shock to pay so much for all the St Petersburg churches and museums. Because the Kazan is a working Orthodox church it is free and well worth visiting. From the outside it is a mini St Peters with a colonnade to match (though about half the size). Inside you can see (or join) the queue of those venerating the icon to the Virgin Mary.
A view on St P. Very interesting cathedral. Try to walk upstair outside the coupola and have a breathtaking view over the roofs of St P

Russian Version of St. Peter's Basilica. Having visited Rome just a year ago, we were amazed to find a cathedral modeled on St. Peter's in downtown St. Petersburg. It is a functioning Russian Orthodox church, so proper dress is required, but it is every bit worth the visit. While much smaller than its Roman model, Kazan Cathedral is beautiful inside and out, and does not have an admission fee or long line up to get in.

Unique church. Very unlike the other churches you'll see, so it's worth a visit (and it's free!) the interior is dark and reminds more of a state building than a church, but it's a nice change of pace from the other cathedrals in the area.

This is a freebie and you don't get many.. A fabulous example of colonnade architecture which was designed with similarity to the Vatican in mind. It is a working church and services were taking place during our visit. It has many interesting internal features and it is good to see that religion still commands great respect. Do however note the warning sign against pick pockets because some will stoop lower than the low if you are momentarily distracted.

One of the main attractions. In a city full of must see churches, museums and other attractions, this is one of you need to squeeze in your schedule. Location is great in Nevsky Prospekt(main street), so you find lots of other things to see and do over there.

Try to fit this one in.. The Church on Spilled Blood and St. Isaac's are the traditional church/museums that tourists see. Try to fit this one in. It is still a functioning church and as such, you are not supposed to take pictures. Some people were, some were not - there was no one screaming at you if you did. It added additional depth to the two days in St. Petersburg to see the local faithful lining up to pay their respects to the Icon of Our Lady of Kazan. The Colonnade out front was to rival St. Peter's in Rome, but it was never fully realized. It is still impressive.

Outside Entrance columns. Impressive entrance that resembles the entrance to St Peter's in Rome and the famous columns that embrace the Cathedral square done by Bernini. Inside again was rather dark and not sure if during religious divine services it it is artificially lite.
Underrated. This place is pretty neat. From the outside, it's a mini St Peters (Rome). The inside is a traditional cathedral. Would seem at home in any European city.

Glorious. Beware, this is not a tourist attraction, but a functioning cathedral, so you can't take photos and women should wear a headscarf. I loved this place and went several times just to observe and feel the atmosphere. A very interesting place to spend some quiet time in.

Big Suprise :). Not what I expected at all from looking at the outside. This church was huge, and beautiful inside. I would have never imagined that from standing out on Nevsky Prospekt. I remember this church being free and would definitely take a peek inside again if I were in St. Petes. You will most likely walk by it multiple times while in the city so you might as well take a look inside. Won't cost you but 15-30 minutes and it is definitely worth it.

tell a tale cathedral. Located on the prominent Nevisky Prospekt is this semicricular Cathedral, the only attraction in St Petersburg without entry fee. The design of Kazan is more or less similar to St Peters of Vatican while It is debatable as to which design was emulated. Now a functional Church after the plunder and pillage of the Soviet regime, it is quite serene to walk in and around this attraction.

High level Russian Orthodox. The sheer size of the building is quiet overwhelming and then you see the decorations inside and it takes your breath away. As a working cathedral a visit during a service is a must to get the full experience (standing only in Russian Orthodox so be prepared!).

A warm reception for the heart of the city. Another great religious monument, that absolutwly cannot be unoticed, placed right in the middle of the Nevsky Prospect, somehow is shadowed by the other big attractions nearby (as Spas na Krovi, Hermitage, Neva Embankment), but still it is an unique attraction. No matter which season, the cathedral invites you for a short walk into it's garden, so that you would be placed in a manner that the Cathedral itself lays around the visitor, just as if it was hugging and wishing a pleasant stay.

Architecture. This Cathedral is all about Architecture, The circular shape of its left/right wings adds something special to this Orthodox shrine. In my opinion, this Cathedral is best enjoyed at nightfall (if the night ever falls at this period of the year...). You can sip a coffee on the opposite side of the Nevsky Prospect and appreciate all the details of the building.

Beautiful Cathedral. A must see, the Icon of Our Lady of Kazan is revered by the locals. A long line of worshippers, it was my understanding, is a daily sight. Worshippers pay their respects and it is one of the most beautiful Icon you will ever see.

Impressive architecture. You may find the decoration of official buildings somewhat overdone, but not the Lady of Kazan Cathedral, an impressive achievement. Try to attend a service if you're not familiar with the Orthodox rites.
Beautiful!. I'm alway in awe of the decoration and architecture of Eurpopean cathedrals - and this one is certainly in my top 4 or 5.
Beautiful Architecture. Like so many of the buildings in St. Petersburg, the architecture is lovely to look at. A working cathedral, but lovely inside. Well worth a visit
Not a museum but a real cathedral. It is worth a stop to see a real cathedral that is in use. Make sure you dress appropriately and bring a scarf to cover your head to show respect.

Not as impressive as others in the city. Whilst this cathedral is very imposing from the outside, personally I found the interior rather dark and gloomy. It's a working cathedral and there are many people observing daily religious rituals, so it's is worthwhile bring a headscarf, wondering around in silence and not taking pictures. It is free to get in, and there are many other attractions nearby. So it's worth popping in if you are passing.

The under-rated cathedral, yet just as pretty as St Isaac. I think Kazan is fundamentally under-rated by travellers, yet its magnificent colonnade at the front is something to truly behold. Some still carry signs of bombardment by the Germans, yet that doesn't take anything away - rather, if anything, it adds to the beauty. You only need about 20-30 minutes to take this place in but it's a great addition to the city tour

main orthodox cathedral. imposing from outside but not very beautiful as the brick work is a dull brown. it is a very religious building and women have to cover their hair upon entering. it is very large inside and no photos are allowed as its the main orthodox cathedral in st petersburg. they ask that you observe silence within the building.

Impressive from the outside, dont bother with the inside. A very impressive building but very dour on the inside and there were numerous unsavoury people waiting outside and just inside with signs warning of criminal activity. Not pleasant inside and if you are tempted to go in be mindful we witnessed a couple of bag attempts with dipping obvious. This is clearly a place of religious values with devout followers, marred by the unsavoury presence of a minority.

A bit out of place, but certainly a great sight. The cathedral is on Nevsky Prospekt, and looks out of place- almost Roman. Its fabulous. I got a cup of coffee just across the street and enjoyed the view.
Unbelievable majesty. It was so mind blowing, gorgeous and breath taking, that you can't say you've been to SPb unless you saw this place.
lovely Cathedral in the nevsky. this lovely Cathedral location is quite weird (as nevsky is busiest street), but.... with the lovely architecture... you can't miss this!

powerful place. Powerful from outside as a monument and very cozy on the inside. It's fascinating to see all this wall decorated with beautiful icons and to think for a moment about all the history that is related to this place.

See the bronze doors. The most impressive things here are the oversize bronze front doors (altho this is not the main entrance), which are an exact copy of Ghiberti's Baptistry doors in Florence, Italy. For those unable to travel to Russia, however, another exact replica of the doors can be seen at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco, CA (and they're better polished, too. . .) The other thing the Kazan Cathedral exemplifies is the curious linkage Russians assign to building cathedrals/churches to commemorate their battles and victories.

Simply a must. Whether you are religious or not, you must see Kazan Cathedral. Not just the outside, but this inside as well. The architecture is gorgeous. I was able to go to a service tonight with a friend and it was the most amazing feeling, something I had never experienced before. I highly recommend this place to everyone, of all ages and religious backgrounds.

Breathtaking. Like others have said, the inside while still impressive, is a letdown after seeing the exterior. Still though this is a great site to see and looks like something out of a fantasy movie.

More impressive outside than inside. A great photo stop, but not an amazing church inside. However, there is no entrance fee, so it is not surprising it is not that brilliant. There was very little information available about the church, so it is probably worth reading up prior to visiting.
OUR LADY OF KAZAN. Stunning exterior - reminiscent of St Peter's in Rome. Interior so-so. Good view of the Cathedral can be had from the Singer Cafe.

Impressive. If you stroll down the Nevsky, it's a worthwhile stop to make.
A perfect spot is to stand on the other side of the road where you have a view of the cathedral on one side and a view on the Spilled Blood church on the other. Breathtaking.
Deeply moving. An historic building - with the flags of e defeated Napoleon and the famous icon - but also a deeply spiritual place.

Very impressive!. It is a landmark of St. Petersburg with Spiritual, historicaly and art importance. It is located in the center of the city on main street Nevsky Prospect. Allow enough time to explore. It is not a quick stop.
Beautiful but no photos. It was nice to see but there where no photos allowed. It was nice to see but there where no photos allowed.

Special ceremony. I happen to visit the cathedral on a Sunday when some special ceremony was taking place. It was quite interesting to see, even if you aren't religious. Everyone stood for the whole service, though people where coming and going during the service, as did I.
Excellent church and history, plus free. You could not get a better Cathedral to view with history and fabulous icons and it is free. Easy as part of the walk of Nevsky Prospekt.

We attended a wedding here, what an experience.. First whilst the wedding was going on people were still visiting the Cathedral so don't be put off if you are there and there is something going on.you can still visit.Apart from having to stand for three hours it was a wonderful experience The inside of the Cathedral is spectacular. We have since been back for a christening which takes place in the cellars.Whilst the outside looks a little tired the inside was magnificent take time to look in all the corners.The chanting by one of the Russian orthodox vicars was also well worth listening to.

Nearly converted on the spot. We happened on a service, and it was a deeply impressive experience. Processional priests, a capella singing (with a deep base included), priests reading in an ancient form of Russian, a real sense of the mystery and magic that most religions have lost. The Gates of Heaven and the rest of the altar area is richly decorated. The rest of the cathedral is dotted with icons, each with a small group of worshippers. Just a lovely space.

Try to Attend a Service in this church!. We were lucky to be on Nevsky Prospect at the time when a service was going on inside this church! The candlelight, haunting melodies of the choir echoing off the tall stone interior and the faithful in prayer made this experience one I won't soon forget. (And be sure to go across the street to Cafe Singer for hot chocolate after!)
Well worth putting your head in the door. Beautiful interior and nice retreat from the cold! Free to enter so worth a look if you're not cathedral-ed out

Beutiful orthodox church. This church is truly a peaceful oasis in the busy city. The calm atmosphere with burning candles combined with some nice artwork, makes this church a must see. There are lots of people worshipping, so you should be a respectful tourist when visiting this place. I even get so see a marriage seremony when I visited.

A working cathedral. Located on Nevsky Prospect opposite the Singer Building is the Cathedral of Our Lady Kazan. What makes this different from other Cathedral's is that it is a working cathedral with services and ceromonies happening all the time. Another benefit is you don't have to wait in line to get in, not crowded and it's free entry.Once inside the cathedral is ornate but not overly so like other cathedral's in St Petersburg. What makes it special are the regular services that take place which gives it a special aura. There are also some very good restaurants located nearby. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful. The exterior is a copy of St. Peter's in Rome on a smaller scale. The stories of the icons were inspiring. The interior was very ornate.
Grand building. This was a very busy cathedral with people actually worshipping so more lively less museum like feeling.
Can't miss and is on main street,. Ams as in st peters in Rome with crypt of most famous russian general who defeated Napoleon. You can go in with no trouble and no lines.
Impressive chandelier and interior. The interior is quite stunning although its pretty dark. Its very peaceful with a large queue to see the Lady. Ladies remember to cover your head

Great architecture, must see. Kazansky Cathedral is one of the key Cathedrals of Saint Petersburg. Beautiful design and architecture you defiantly want to come inside. The icons are beautiful. I absolutely love that Cathedral, you can feel the special spirit when you visit it.

Imposing and impressive. A very imposing church, although the entry was hidden away due to renovations being undertaken at the time of our visit. Inside the church is magnificent.The current renovations are external and the restored columns are almost cream after the dirt and grime of age and pollution are removed.

Reminds you of Roman Architecture.. The second best cathedral I have seen after the Vatican. The architecture reminds you of the Roman ones with tall colonnaded portico. The garden in front is very well maintained and is a delight to spend some quality time. The inside of the Church needs to be seen to be believed. It's just Grand and we visited at a time when the prayer was going on and the organ played later on. It transferred me to some other world. But sadly photography or videography inside the church is not permitted, otherwise I could have bought back its memories along with me.
Gorgeous structures both day and night. You can miss it along Nevsky Prospect. Very impressive structure. Stroll through it. Just watch your purse and lens of your SLR camera.

Worth seeing it!. It is an orthodox church. Inside is discrete and full of icons. They do not charge to go inside. Just be respectful. Do not wear short pants or muscle shirts. For men a nice t-shirt and pants is enough. For women long skirts and a shall to cover their head is acceptable. Do not walk with your hands inside your pockets.
big church. enjoyed this church more from the outside...very big and grey inside although there were some interesting things to see, so if you have the time, check it out

classical elegance. it is not the most extravagant or grand. but the beautiful romanisque exterior with tall strait architectural line, i think makes it the most elegent yet grand building in the city center.
Kazandky Sobor. Just grndeur and art, and artwork. sorry that we don't have weeks to walk and take in the magnificence. And the poor common people barely make it on their paultry salaries.

Impressive from outside and inside. A miniature of Vatican's St Peter , the church is attractive nevertheles and above all in ..very convenient location along Nevsky Avenue. So easily you can check the interior at no cost. Is an active church so dress properly.

include a part of your Nevsky Prospekt tour. It's interesting and imposing ... somewhat forbidding, certainly not my favourite church or cathedral in St. Petersburg. Still ...worth stopping by on your walking tour of Nevsky (especially since the kafe Singer is just across the street).

Much recommended. Located on the Nevsky prospekt, this church is different to other Orthodox churches in St Petersburg. It was built by an Italian architect and reminds the italian Basilica. Very grand and free entry.
Great cathedral. A must to visit if in St.Petersburg. It gives you an idea of an Orthodox church. Nice interior and atmosphere.

Imposing from the outside. This cathedral is very imposing from the exterior and we weren't even sure what the structure was until we got up close. It lacks the opulence inside of other cathedrals in the city but it's interesting. I wouldn't make a special trip to see this one but if you're walking by (it's right on Nevsky Prospekt), then do stop.
Old big church. Very nice building and very old. It's not renovated so you can see the oldness of it all over the building .

Very moving when there is an active worship service. I actually was more moved by my time spent inside Our lady of Kazan than I was by St Isaacs or Spilled Blood. Those two were so full of people taking pictures that one could not see let alone really connect emotionally with the surroundings.This was the first active Orthodox worship service I had seen, but tourists seemed welcome to walk around and observe the service and view the tomb of the warrior who fought Napoleon. There was a long line of people waiting to pray to the Icon of Our Lady as well as a roped-off area where people were praying. Orthodox women were all in headscarves. I was worried about my sleeveless shirt and not having anything that I could use to cover my shoulders, but that did not seem to be a problem as many people were in tank tops, etc. There is a garden area out front with benches, and it was a nice early evening in summer, so many people were gathered there also. I recommend!

Combination of active place of worship and classical architecture landmark. Loose your way between the columns outside. The effect is especially striking in the night.When you enter go to the right. This is the tomb of great field marshal Kutuzov along with banners captured from Napoleon armies and keys of fallen cities.This is working church so follow Russian tradition: man should take their hat off and women cover their hair.No charge entrance.
Soothing and Uplifting. Fromt he hustle and bustle on the Nevsy Prospect this is an oasis of calm.A service was in progress which enhanced the experience.I left revived and enthused.
Impressive but overwhelming. Overcrowded by peeps just hanging out, seems like a big rendez-vous point :)

Hey, no charge, can you believe it!. I got so tired of being charged for everything (including bathrooms) in St. Petersburg. Therefore, I was surprised not to be charged to go into this church. Quite impressive structure and if you are a believer, you will make this a pilgrimage.
Our Lady of Kazan Cathedral. Free admission and conveniently located, recommend stop.
Visit it before Isaac Cathedral and Church of our Savoir on the Blood. This cathedral is in restoration process now, and could be seen gloomy and grey after the above mentioned two cathedrals.
Very Russian. Great place and full of history. Don't miss the Kutuzov tomb.
Full of history. it is something I would define as strongly and typically Russian: monumental, with the Napoleon flags, icons,...
No words..... There was a service going on when we visited the place. So quiet and peaceful still...
A true religious experience.. Beautiful church with amazing architecture. Stand on line and pray in front of the saint. Tradition has it that if you need a miracle she will answer your prayers.

Breathtaking. We were lucky to be there on a Sunday and heard the service. The spiritual ambience was electrifying. And soon after we heard music from the choir group floating down from the first floor. We were floored and did not want to move. This is a Russian Orthodox Church. Pictures are not allowed inside. The cathedrals in Russia are built in a manner the priest can be heard from any corner of the cathedral without the use of mikes. The choir also sings without mikes or musical instruments. But are they melodious!!! U do not feel anything missing. Understand earthen pots are placed in the roofs of the cathedrals which assists in the marvellous acoustics. Needless to say the icons, the frescoes and mural are beautiful.
Classic Collonade. Superb classical architecture, another stunning interior of this working church opposite the singer sewing machine building
In the city center. Near Nevskiy and Fontanka - must visit place! Go inside and injoy the beaty!
magnificent. Very central.. Looks like Rome. You may have a rest in park which takes part in front of the cathedral..
Beautiful. Very nice , not my favorite but not to be passed up.

Unique. Unique in that this is a functioning Russian Orthodox church. Ladies, be sure to have a head covering. Men, remove your hats. We were fortunate to arrive during a service--really other-wordly! We also saw worshippers on line to venerate the icon of Our Lady of Kazan. Our visit was a window into a very fascinating world
Beautiful. Must-see if you're in St.Petersburg. Located on the Nevsky prospekt, you just can't pass it by.
Disappointing. disappointing - whilst impressive from the out side the shape is likened to an eagle spreading its wings - it was really quite dull inside
Best seen from Singer Cafe. Looks good at ground level, from one floor up in the Singer Cafe, it is stunning

Beautiful Interiors and Exterior!. Must see this church (entry is free!).. centrally located, and has a grand first impact on you! Lovely monument to photograph and the interiors are as aesthetically pleasing as the exteriors.. def take a peak inside, esp as there is no entry charge!
WONDERFUL!!!. One of the most beautiful cathedrals! It is worth visiting every time you are in St. Pete

Definitely worth a visit. When we walked in the coir was singing when we got there and we got to see the last part of the church service. We drank some blessed water for good health and admired the cathedral's interior, with its numerous columns and an outward colonnade. The interior features numerous sculptures and icons executed by the best Russian artists of the day.The inside is definitely more impressive than the outside!!

to pray. don't forget the Icone of our Lady of Kazan which protect Moscow and St Petersburg of tyrans and destruction... if in town for Easter come to our Easter service from 11 till 1am - last longer but just amazing voices from the Chrorus !

Well.... a nice place to see. It is very good located - right on the cross of Nevsky ave and Griboyedov channel. From the main street of the city you can see a charming view of the Cathedral, which is very beautiful from the outside. When you get closer, you see a lot of poor people, who ask for money, some children, other people you will not want to get closer to... It's relatively safe, but better not to play with the faith. Entrance is free. The Cathedral houses of the most important icons of Russian Orthodox church. During the religious holidays, there're long queues to enter the Cathedral.

vast and atmospheric. Many churches housed museums of atheism during the Soviet era, and this cathedral was no exception. It's now restored to its role as a place of worship, and is well frequented. Women should cover the head when entering any Russian church, but it's fine to go in even during a service. There are no pews and people are just sort of standing or milling about, kissing the icons and so on. There are signs up to beware of pickpockets, however... even in church.

Operating Cathedral. It is open at 9am and is free because people actually come here to pray before going to work!Women folk cover their heads, so prepare a scarf.There's nothing much to see here anyway,.. so, just photograph the outside and hop on over to the church of our saviour who spilled blood, which is a museum now

Extraordinary towering catherdral. Loved the magnificent and towering exterior. Very different from the catherdrals found in Europe or North America. Still bears testimony of the brutal wounds of WWII on the exteriour. Blasts from mortars, bullets and tankshells but fortunately not worse.
Very impressive. Impressive and humbling. Please no photos, to respect services going on.

Very moving. We visited more than once. Lucky enough to be staying nearby, we saw Kazan daily. On our first visit, we saw a mass being held and confession being held. Very different than I've known in the Russian Orthodox Church back home.

Doesn't look like much from the outside, but go in!. This looks like the most European of the churches we saw, but upon entering it was the only church we visited that seemed alive and full of spirit. LOVED it! Babushkas kissing icons and lighting candles, people lined up in a long line at one particular icon, thick clouds of incense.......free to enter but consider making a donation and lighting a candle.
What an affection!. Russians stand in huge lines in order to light her a candle and ask for something, it's amazing to see this side of the russian culture!

Worth a look. This is a active church so they don't charge you to get in, that said the place needs a clean and a renovation. There are long queues to offer devotion at the famous icon so it's hard to get a look at this but it is the overall place is worth seeing.
Must See!. Centrally located & free (donations toward restoration are nice!). Magnificent.

Rather disappointing. Having seen the other reviews perhaps we had over-raised our expectations about this Cathedral. Also having already visited the St Nicholas, St Isaacs and Peter & Paul Fortress Cathedrals we were rather disappointed with The Cathedral of our Lady of Kazan. The outside architecture is odd with huge 'wings leading to the entrance seemingly without any purpose. Inside the Church is relatively plain and dark without anything significant to see. All in all- not as good as expected.

Impressive cathedral inspired by the basilica of St. Peter’s in Rome.. This impressive Russian orthodox cathedral, named after the "miraculous" icon of Our Lady of Kazan, is located at: 2, Nevsky Prospekt, Kazanskaya Square. It's interior boasts impressive columns, sculptures and icons by a variety of famous russian artists.

A Russian Orthodox experience. The working Russian Orthodox central cathedral is quite imposing on Nevsky Prospekt and decidedly non-Russian in style. With no entrance fee to marvel at the inside (no photos), it is a must. It appears to be in the midst of a clean-up on the outside.
Must see. It is in the centre, and a great Cathedral, we really enjoyed it.

My favourite site. I personally found this to be my favourite site just by grand presence in the centre of Nevskiy Prospekt.There is a great restaurant at the top of the building behind the Cathedral to the right. They have a outdoor patio on the 6th floor.
Impressive outside and dark inside. We happened to visit on a special day where the russians were all collecting water inside the church and it was very very crowded so difficult to see as much.
Moving. If you can go when there is a service on then it's a very moving experience.
Lovely choir. This ancient, ancient cathedral, dismal on the outside, is as beautiful inside as any onion-clad Russian church. An ancient example of Byzantium, it is not to be missed.

very impressive. It is really huge and beautiful. Must see. You will be impressed

Brilliant!. A real gem in St. Petersburg. Worth a visit inside to see all the colorful icons, frescoes, and the services.

Wandered inside one evening and watched a service in progress, beautiful singing. Impressive inside and out. Went in one evening and quietly observed a service going on. A choir high in a loft and a priest were singing beautifully. Very special atmosphere. Definitely worth a look.
Beautiful Cathedral. I really love orthodox churches, worth visiting! It's a beautiful church...

A Holy Place. This is a true, working church, filled when we were there, in the middle of the day, with many worshippers, mostly women. I loved it here. Quiet. Peaceful. A place to contemplate Russian history, and be thankful for the survival, through the years of Communist rule, of this cathedral. A place to reflect on the survival of the faith of the Russian people. A deeply spiritual place. Also, as it is a church, and not a museum, entrance is free. Worth lighting a candle or two.
Right on Nevsky Prospekt. Beautiful cathedral where you will find many locals paying respects and lighting candles. Short stroll from the Spilled Blood Church. Beautiful inside!

Looks like it needs a clean. I was disappointed. Having been to St.P a number of times I tried to do the attractions that I hadn't done or were on the top list. It is an imposing building and probably the weather dint put it in good light as it had been raining all day and the area in the front of the cathedral was packed with parked cars and hard to get around with all the standing water. Was quiet inside with very few visitors and a few buckets capturing leaking water. What is impressive fare the colonnades drawing you into the building.All around are parked tourist buses
Major Church. This is the largest and main Russian Orthodox church in St Petersburg. A steady trail of folk queue to worship at a major icon each day while even more attend prayers each evening.

Amazing and fulfilling - definitely worth a visit. You don't need to be Christian or orthodox to admire an amazing building and culture! or to appreciate and respect the people praying inside. The church has seen better days but don't let this put you off, but rather let it add to the experience of realism. Not everything needs to be shiny and freshly painted to be admired.This is not meant to be a tourist attraction, it's an active church and doesn't get the tourist funding of the decommissioned churches. I recommend you go in and see the intricate details inside and if you can, get there for a service / the choir. Be sure to observe a few things: do not use your camera, be respectful, take in a scarf for your head (for the ladies).It's worth it to experience an active orthodox church.

Off Nevsky Prospekt, not far from Church of our Lady on Spilled Blood. A distant second or third in terms of attractiveness, far less impressive than the famous Church of our Lady on Spilled Blood. We visited mid afternoon and found few people inside, making the visit to the Kazan Cathedral nice. The exterior is not too attractive, looked tired and in need of a cleaning. The inside wasn't a lot better, offering some decor to admire but was very dark at the time of our visit, making photography conditions quite poor. We sat on some benches inside and admired the ceiling and wall paintings for a while, probably spent 20 minutes altogether before being on our way to the next attraction. Overall, we found it difficult to recommend the Kazan Cathedral off Nevsky Prospect unless you've significant time in St. Petersburg. Its not a highlight so make sure you see more important attractions first. If time remains, you can try to squeeze this one in.

St Petersburg’s main cathedral. The Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan (also known as Kazan Cathedral) is St Petersburg’s major Russian Orthodox cathedral. It is located in the city’s central street, Nevsky Prospect. During the Soviet era, its building was used to house the Museum of the History of Religion and Atheism, but now it is active again as a church.Try to get there around 10 o’clock in the morning to listen to one of the best church choirs in the city singing at the morning liturgy. Organ music is not used in Russian churches – all services are accompanied by a capella singing.Inside, the classical décor of the church is quite impressive. The exquisite iconostasis used to be made of solid silver, but was melted down during the Soviet era, so its present-day replica is just covered with silver leaf. The wonder-working icon of Our Lady of Kazan, found in the city of Kazan at the time of Ivan the Terrible’s rule, is to the left of the iconostasis – you will see people lining up in front of the icon to kiss it and pray to it.The cathedral, completed in 1811, became a memorial of Russia’s victory over Napoleon won in 1812, and the famous Field Marshall Kutuzov was buried inside it. If you enter the cathedral from Nevsky Prospect (which is actually a side entrance - the main one is from a side street), you will see his gravestone right opposite the entrance. Besides, one of the two statues in front of the cathedral represents Kutuzov (the other one features Barclay de Tolly, the other General who commanded Russian army during the Napoleonic War).Russian Orthodox churches have rather strict rules, so make sure you do not use your camera inside and do not talk loudly. Shorts and short skirts are not recommended, and men are requested to take their hats off when they enter a church. Postcards and booklets of the church are available in the gift shop, which also has a big choice of inexpensive small-sized icons.
